136125866.review:
Big Pharma is a tycoon game with a unique twist - the game focuses on automating and optimizing the production of pharmaceuticals. Players will have to balance their resources, research new drugs, and design their factories to create the most efficient assembly lines possible.

The game's strength lies in its automation aspect, which is both challenging and satisfying to master. Designing and optimizing your factory is a fun experience, and the game does a good job of introducing new mechanics at a steady pace.

However, the tycoon side of the game feels a bit basic compared to other games in the genre. While it's certainly serviceable, it lacks the depth and complexity that other tycoon games offer.

Overall, Big Pharma is a fun but short-lived experience. It's definitely worth picking up on sale, but the full price tag may not be justified given the game's limited replay value. If you're a fan of automation or tycoon games, it's definitely worth checking out.

Lots of complaints about it are really non complaints in my opinion. If your product isn't selling, drop the price by 3% every week until it starts selling. Or figure out why it isn't selling. Did you lose a patent race? Are you being undercut by a competitor? It adds another neat dynamic to the game that also makes competitors mean something. In addition, if your stuff is selling well and you're just not making enough profit to get that next warehouse expansion, bump up your prices by 3% every week until they stop selling, then drop by 3% and leave it. Sure it needs tweaking every so often. But if you're having to change your prices literally every second of the game, you're doing something wrong.

108841571.review:
I've really only scratched the surface of the entire game, but I can say that what I have played definitely is fun.  It scratches that Tycoon-series-type itch.  Any game where you build stuff and try to make money has a chance when it comes to that, but this game adds a lot of depth and challenge into what you have to do to succeed.  You really have only one job, and that's building assembly lines for pharmaceutical products.  But that job can be pretty tricky.  In order to produce a product you have to adjust the concentration levels of base ingredients in order to activate positive effects.  At the same time you have to try to mitigate or remove negative side effects.  Doing so requires a tailor made process line for each and every drug you make, and working out a good process to produce the best product without spending too much money is the puzzle at the heart of this game.  As you unlock more advanced options and begin to create more powerful drugs, it becomes necessary to add other base ingredients which have to be adjusted prior to mixing... it can be a real headache, usually in a good way.  Add to that the need to discover more ingredients, research new technologies, and compete with rival companies... it can get complicated; again, in a good way.

However the one negative I have is that the financial aspect of the game is confusing.  Time is measured in days, and each time you see a conveyor move a product down the line, a day has passed.  On the company tab where you track your finances, each drug is shown with the amount of profit each drug produces.  At the same time, your overall profit per day is tracked on a corner counter.  This counter will never match the total of your drugs' profit amounts, for reasons that are not shown.  At times, even though your financial counter shows that you have are making profit and have an overall positive profit margin, your daily counter will drop into the red while you are building a new line that is partially running.  It seems clear that the reason is the overhead costs for running the machinery exceed the current profit for a time, but this is never explicitly shown or made available to you.  I don't have a real affinity for finances, but it's usually simple math, as long as all the numbers are there for you to see. Not having the full financial picture means it is very easy to get into financial ruin early on.

It's worth mentioning that when working through scenarios, a significant time investment is needed for each one.  (You can save at any point, of course.)

Overall though, this is a pretty good game.  Some tweaks could make it really great.

Boring grind fest. So I will place here a recipe for huckleberry pancakes instead.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside. In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs. Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the best job). Fry at 400 degrees. Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown. Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).

97946121.review:
Introduction

Drugs!  Who doesn’t like drugs?  But what’s better than drugs?  Selling drugs!  To kids!  (No, not really. Don’t sell drugs to anyone, least of all kids.  Unless you work in an actual pharmacy, in which case, please accept my most heartfelt condolences.)

‘Big Pharma’ lets you step into the expensive, patent leather shoes of the Martin Shkrelis of the world, where you generate obscene profits by price gouging sick people for the medicine they need so they don’t die.  It could just as easily have been called ‘Garbage Human Simulator’, to be honest.  If you’re hell-bent on becoming a remorseless pirate but you hate the sea, and aren’t terribly enthused about wrangling a crew of murderous cut-throats who will likely butcher you in your sleep as soon as the grog runs dry, then there’s probably a role for you in the pharmaceutical industry.  (You could, if you’re that way inclined, use your powers for good and actually work on developing drugs that make the world a less awful place in which to live… *pause for raucous laughter* …yeah, I didn’t think so.  If OxyContin has taught us anything, it’s that it’s all about the money. Ka-ching!)

So, without further ado, let’s exploit the suffering of others for fun and profit!

Gameplay

First off, play the tutorials.  All of them.  This game gets fairly complicated fairly quickly, and having a vague idea of what you’re supposed to be doing at any given time is advantageous.  Secondly, while you’re playing through the tutorials, pay attention.  Read stuff.  Comprehend that stuff.  Put that stuff into practice, and make sure it works as intended before you move on.  Borderline criminal pharmaceutical empires are rarely built by people who “kinda” know what they’re doing.  Moving on…

You start the game with a production facility. It’s quite small, and you’re going to need room to expand in short order, but Rome wasn’t built in a day.  In the walls of this facility are input/output ports.  As you might expect, raw ingredients enter the facility via one of these ports, and a finished drug leaves.  All the interesting stuff happens in between.  At its most basic level, Big Pharma has you building conveyor belts which transport raw ingredients along a production chain littered with various machines.  These machines take an ingredient and do something to it, then deposit it back onto the conveyor belt where it travels to the next machine, and so on.  Each raw ingredient has various characteristics which dictate what sort of cure you’re able to derive from it.  Some ingredients can produce multiple cures, some can be chemically upgraded to provide a different cure, or a better, more profitable version of an existing cure — all of which is done by funnelling ingredients into different machines at different concentrations.

As GlaxoSmithKline, Pfizer, and friends can no doubt testify, you can make an awful lot of money very quickly by selling drugs.  Which is just as well, because everything costs money. Expanding your facility costs money.  Building machines and belts costs money. Hiring explorers to discover new ingredients, scientists to research new technology, and executives to oversee manufacturing and marketing; it all costs a stonking great wheelbarrow-load of money.  And it only takes a few terrible decisions to turn a profitable enterprise into an insolvent ruin.  Fortunately, the game lets you slow down or stop the passing of time to give you a few moments to contemplate your next executive decision.

When you’ve worked your way through the tutorials, Big Pharma provides a range of scenarios tiered by difficulty.  As a beginner, you might be tasked with making a profit of $1,000,000 in ten years with only one competitor.  At the other end of the spectrum, you start out with $250,000 in debt and must produce four entirely different cures, all of which have a market price of over $500. Oh, and you have a paltry six years in which to do it.  Good luck with that stress-induced ulcer.  If you’d rather just mess about a bit in the factory, then there’s a custom game mode which lets you tweak a variety of parameters to provide a more casual experience.  (Or a more punishing experience if you’re a hopeless masochist with a penchant for failure.)  It’s a bit like Minecraft, except you have access to corrosive chemicals and virulent neurotoxins.

Graphics

Big Pharma’s simple, colourful, cartoony graphical style works really well.  Everything is highly-detailed, vibrant and pleasant to look at.  Given how complicated some of your production chains can get, it would have been easy to have the whole thing become an indecipherable mess where trying to figure out which machine is doing what triggers a migraine.  Not so, here.  The UI is well laid out and easy to navigate, and the little puffs of smoke and flashes of lightning as the machines work their magic are a joy to behold.  The font could perhaps be a tad larger, but that’s a trivial complaint at best.

Sound

Nothing much of note here.  The music is your plain vanilla-flavoured background beeping and bopping, which is probably what you want when you’re trying to concentrate on the finer points of chemistry and marketing.  I tend to turn the music down in games like this because it becomes more of a distraction than an enhancement, and Big Pharma is no different.  It’s not horrible or anything; it’s just sort of… there.  Like wallpaper.

Sound effects are a standard collection of whirs, clicks, buzzes, and clanks you might expect as ambient noise in any production facility.  It’s all quite effective in giving the impression of a sophisticated drug laboratory hard at work churning out sedatives and anti-depressants for the overworked and unfulfilled masses.

Performance

I’m running Big Pharma on a 2012 Lenovo Thinkpad with integrated graphics, and while my ancient toaster gets a little on the warm side, I’ve yet to experience any lag, stutter, or critical warp core failures.  It seems to chug along quite happily, even after extended play.  The game screams along effortlessly on my desktop machine, so unless your rig is powered by an arthritic hamster on a rusty wheel, you should have no problems here.

Conclusion

If you’ve ever wanted to manufacture  and distribute drugs, but don’t want to be beheaded by Colombian drug cartels and left to rot in the desert, or spend the rest of your natural life in prison (if you don’t get shanked in the showers first), then Big Pharma is probably a viable alternative to ruining your life and suffering an unnecessarily grisly demise.  The game gives you ample opportunity to take a more altruistic route, but you can behave like an amoral, profiteering bucket of human effluvia if you so desire.  Let your conscience be your guide… and think about all those people who have to drive to Canada just to get some damn insulin.

Despite being both stressful and quite complicated (keeping track of concentration levels, catalyst availability, market saturation, and your steadily depleting funds will give you grey hairs and worry lines), Positech have created a fun, clever game, that is both engaging and well executed.  I give it a solid seven Panadols out of ten.  (Always follow the instructions and see your doctor if pain persists.)

This was one of my first PC games. I played it in beta before it was on Steam and I loved it. I've revisited it six years later and while I previously called it a basic game, I've found that it's a lot more complex than I first thought and have been enjoying every moment of it.

I'm nowhere near done with the game, I previously had only completed the beginner levels and on my revisit I've not even moved on from the first level as I wanted to replay it just for fun, sinking another few hours into the game.

84156257.review:
I really enjoyed this game, because I came at it from the perspective of someone who played a lot of Rollercoaster Tycoon and other management games. Nowadays, a much closer touchstone for this game is something like Factorio. You choose a product to make, lay out the necessary component pieces, then assemble them into as tight and compact a space as possible.
There are a large number of scenarios which can keep the game fresh, but the game has a limited core ruleset - this helps make it accessible, but you are eventually going to see the complete ruleset and know a priori how to solve any given problem with the tools you have. By exploring deeper into the scenarios, you will be forced to modify this to solve the problems at hand, but the core structure will remain the same. 
The ruleset limitation isn't necessarily bad - the issue is that you will only find a limited number of 'cure families', each which always upgrade the same way, and so that 'problem' of "How do I cure X?" will always have the same answer, once you've gained some experience.
This also ties into the business aspect - there really isn't much you have to do there. You will ultimately be just fine treating  this like a factory game for most of it - until you get into a couple of challenges in the scenarios. Don't come into this thinking you're going to actually be dealing a lot with marketing and corporate subterfuge.

While I would certainly say that I've had a positive experience in the handful of hours I've played it, it is certainly not without its drawbacks. Big Pharma follows the pretty basic factory puzzle game format but imposing it over the world of pharmaceutics is a unique approach. It took me awhile to get acclimated with all the tools and important optimization aspects to be mindful of as I feel like it has a high learning curve, but hanging in there is more than worthwhile. The ingredients and the drugs you can make out all have different requirements and balancing cost efficiency and therapeutic benefit is a fun challenge. As you continue to make your product lines more complex, it is immensely gratifying when you uncover ways to optimize your work flow and use one machine for multiple drugs. Though racing the clock and your competitors is fun, pausing time and perfecting your builds before continuing eliminates this stress. That being said, this feature is a godsend for new players. Though I feel like ending of a run is underwhelming, I find it difficult to complain as Big Pharma is highly repayable and is at a price point that is more than fair. I wouldn't call it a must have, but it would be a fine addition to your library if you are already a fan of this genre of games. 

TL;DR- good game but buyers beware if not fan of puzzle building games and steep learning curves

81735636.review:
As a lover of production-chain management games, this really hits the spot for me. In Big Pharma, you use machinery to process raw ingredients into medicine to sell for profit. While the concept is simple, there are so many different elements you need to manage to really maximise efficiency and revenue, for example:
[list]
[*] Machines all have unique sizes and shapes and you have limited space to build on, so it's a game of Tetris to cram everything in as densely as possible. This gives you lots of choices - do you use lots of cheap machines to keep your processing costs low or use expensive machines that take up a lot less space? You might be able to improve a production chain with a new machine that you just unlocked, but this could mean re-organising the entire floor to get everything squeezed in.
[*] The ingredients you use come with a variety of different qualities, some of which are dangerous side effects that drag down the quality of your final product. There are a number of ways to manage these effects or remove them completely but you will need to experiment to find the most profitable method.
[*] You only start with a small number of ingredients and machines. You will need staff to unlock new ones to really make the big bucks, but these staff also demand quite a hefty salary which can hemorrhage your early profits. You may need to take out big risky loans in order to hit tight deadlines. 
[*] You compete against rival companies which can effect you in a number of ways. If you make the same kind of cures as your competitors, your profits will fall as the market becomes more saturated. You can also patent a product so that no one else can make it, but your competitors can also do this to block you.
[*] Your ingredients and layout are randomised each game, which helps keep the game feeling fresh over multiple challenges.
[/list]
The only criticism I would give Big Pharma is that the scope of the game feels pretty limited. You spend most of your time moving stuff around in your relatively small laboratory and then you might flick through some other tabs for details of your research, competitors, etc. The "levels" simply consist of a list of different challenges to complete (e.g. make $1,000,000 within 5 years). The game could have done with a bit more narrative - they could have given you reasons for why you have certain objectives, or maybe some actual interaction with your competitors, to make you feel a bit more invested.

72024987.review:
Big Pharma is a simulation game that (speaking as someone who actually works in the industry) presents an fantasized and wholly inaccurate portrayal of how a pharmaceutical company is run. The game mostly revolves around researching new compounds and building manufacturing lines to formulate those compounds into effective drugs. There are multiple ways to do this however, some of which are more efficient and/or require less space than others. You are also working against three other competitor companies, each of which may undercut your products either by offering similar medications at a lower price or more effective drugs.

The gameplay is hectic, dynamic, and requires a lot of problem solving. Figuring out what the best way to formulate your products and selling them at a profit gets more challenging as the game goes on. Buying additional manufacturing space is expensive, so arranging all your manufacturing lines efficiently is also a big part of the game. Competitors add an additional facet to the game and can undercut your business plans in multiple ways. 

I do wish that the game would more accurately reflect what goes on in the pharma industry, however. Most companies spend more money on advertisements meant to push drugs on consumers that don't need them than on actual R&D. There should also be options to increase the price of your drugs by 7352%, lobby corrupt politicians for corporate tax breaks, and pay off regulators so that unsafe and ineffective products make it onto market. 

Overall, still very fun and highly recommended.

As a 2nd-year pharmacy student, I found this game right after I wrapped up our Medicinal Chemistry finals. One of the last topics we covered happened to be drug research and development and the FDA approval process. Although this game is certainly NOT an entirely faithful depiction of what (can) happen in drug R&D and approval, the challenge of making products with maximal effects and minimal to no side effects is as true in-game as in the real world (especially given our current circumstances with the COVID-19 pandemic).

The only thing I'd like now is for more compounds and more effects (side effects and therapeutic ones) to be added in-game! I've already cured Alzheimer's 3 times in my last runthroughs!

70865093.review:
All the parts of this game work OK.  I enjoyed learning how to play, and how to use the machines to make drugs.  The designers came up with a lot of clever/creative mechanisms for manipulating and combining drugs/effects.

But once you basically understand how to play and how to use the machines to get the effects you want, often this whole part of the game (placing machines/belts in your factory) just feels like a chore.  And if you're trying to maximize profits, you end up doing a ton of this - tearing down lines, building the same simple lines repeatedly, and copying more complex lines from one place to another.  Occasionally this requires a bit of thinking to fit the line into a different shaped factory room - but often it's just repetitive tedium.  

I did a couple tutorials, then a beginner scenario, then jumped into the advanced ones.

In my second advanced run, I was pretty close to making the "master" goal, but realized that to reach the goal I was going to have to tear down a couple long lines and refactor them to increase production.  There was enough space that I was sure I could do it... and I just didn't want to.  I just didn't want to click all those buttons (and I'm a person who likes Factorio).

The "placing machines" part of the game is the interesting part.. but it gets old fast once you've learned the mechanics.  The overarching game - deciding what to research and which drugs to make - doesn't really have enough going on to be interesting on its own, and you end up making bad decisions in that game just because you're bored of tinkering around with the other part.  Like, after a while you just ignore the world events, or whether your competitors are horning in on your cough syrup racket or whatever, because you just can't be bothered to pick up that line and try to find something else to go there.  The 4% increase in profit is just not worth 200 more clicks.

Anyway, if this is on sale, it's maybe worth getting it for the initial joy of discovery.  But it doesn't hold up well enough to justify full price.

70796257.review: While I recommend this game, I would say that most negative comments on this game are not totally unfounded. I think it's a time management/puzzle game rather than a true simulation/management game. Initially, it has a pretty big learning curve. Once you discover a couple higher level machines and some tricks, it become more of a game that you set up nearly the same way every single time. I caught myself pausing the game, hiring 2 scientists for the same tasks, then using nearly the same progression. However, I love the puzzle aspects as far as how creatively can I make money, or patent a product to cut off a competitors main money making strategy. Personally, I would not buy the game without the DLC, but it does require a little more micromanaging to be successful. All in all, it was a very fun and worthwhile purchase, and a game that wasn't terrible to beat all the scenarios.

70647722.review: So this is a cross between a business sim and kind of a puzzle game. You're running a pharma company and have to create profitable drugs and sell them, and have to also set up the assembly lines for drug production in the limited space that you're given. It's an interesting idea, with the combined pressures of turning a profit and making enough money to continue expanding, while also your drug production has to get more and more complex, taking up more space, requiring more machinery and more elaborate conveyor belt setups. It's satisfying early on but as things get more complicated it just felt like an ever increasing headache, without any tools like being able to save blueprints of assembly lines to make things a little smoother, so you just find yourself manually creating the same production setups over and over. So I felt less like I was being challenged and more like I was being asked to waste my time.

I'm going to give this game a weak recommendation, but there are some problems to address.  First of all, the game performs mostly well, but there is an incredible problem on my PC with it hanging and not releasing control of the window, thus forcing me to log out of Windows 10.  This is a moderate inconvenience because I have lost saves because of it.  

Second of all, the gameplay involves way too much planning and there's not a lot of joy in just watching your creations.  You're always having to think well ahead and that often meant pausing the game for long stretches for me until I figured out the exact solution to a particular problem.  The actual process of making money and selling drugs doesn't go beyond "Awesome, I didn't screw up the design." 

The reason I'm recommending this is because, if you treat this game like moer of a puzzle game than a management game, it is amazing.  , trying to find out how to manage space and cost efficiently, balancing research and profit, when to take out loans, when to pay off loans, balancing the quality of your drugs with the cost of producing them, finding out which delivery method is best, find that design that gives you one extra block of space so you can cram everything you need into your lab.  Given that outside of world events and competition not a lot changes, this is an endless puzzle, and the satisfaction is in figuring it out rather than actually managing things.

60604422.review:
Big Pharma is a tycoon game, that is, your objective is generally go bigger, better and richer. In order to do so you need to produce and sell drugs, which is done through an assembly line puzzle that happens in a little space in your factory. The game centers around the efficiency of your production design and market sellability of your drug.

Even after you finished the production line you will find yourself with a drug that perhaps has too much side effects, or it isn't very effective at all, or your competitor released a better one and it just won't sell, or even a myriad of other problems. It is a game of constant error and mistakes, then rethinks e fixes, and that makes it engaging and enjoyable.

The art style is gorgeous to say the least. It is cartoony and colorful just as the screenshots show. The soundtrack is pretty good, it also makes pleasant "lab sounds" as the machines work and as you scroll and click through the menus. 

The DLC release made the game perfect. PLEASE BUY THE DLC. It added a lot of features related to market control: nicer graphs, stock control machines, advertisement, etc. It is awesome and i can't stress enough how much I enjoyed it, please play it.

55183088.review:
I bought this game (and the DLC) after buying Production Line a while back. I was hesitant because while I enjoyed Production Line for what it was, it definitely had a shelf life because of the static gameplay. In that game, you'd basically research things, add them to your cars, maybe have to add a machine to install them, and adjust your sales price accordingly. Not much depth beyond that point. I feared this game would present the same problem. It does not. 

There's a complexity to this that was exactly what I had hoped Production Line would include, or at least release a DLC at some point to address that issue. In this game, you're kind of doing the same stuff, but in many ways, you're not. You set up your production lines in similar fashion, but it's not a simple process of research, add, sell. Products include an array of issues you need to solve to get them right. You need to consider things like balancing your concentration level to avoid side effects, or you can use machines to eliminate those side effects. You need catalysts to complete upgrades, you'll have to adjust your concentration levels for your upgraded products, there's a machine to package them in larger quantities to make your process more cost efficient. All of these things take up space. Then there's the usual research with upgrades, ingredient discovery with upgrades, sales reps that can give you an edge over the competition, etc. There is just a lot to this, and it will make you plan ahead and adjust as you go. 

The campaign is much better planned out in comparison to Production Line as well. It feels more in depth, competitors feel more involved and will really try to hurt your sales. The whole game just feels much more polished. I suppose that makes sense considering it's been out for several years, but they definitely got it right. I'd recommend picking it up on sale if you can, the retail price is a bit steep.

51095133.review:
Excellent game if you fancy a bit of puzzle work, cashflow balancing and constructing production chains. Graphically it looks great - it's not your fancy 3D artwork that you might find elsewhere, but the simplistic graphics fit really well and mean you can run it on lower end machines as well.

49718124.review:
TL;DR: It's a basic management game that might be fun for some hours, but it does not feel finished and it's not worth it at this price point.

So I had this game on my wishlist for a long time, but was not sure I would like it.
I've always had a big thing for management-games and base building, so it did seem interesting enough from that viewpoint, but it does look quite bland and linear.

It turns out this first impression was not wrong.
I'll try to be fair about it, but here are some points:

Pro's:
 - Got the basic management thing down
 - Puzzling your production lines together can be challenging
 - Research for new machines and exploration for new ingredients feels good
 - Extensive tutorials and missions to scale up your knowledge and challenges

Con's:
 - The tutorial is riddled with typo's, and in some other places as well
 - The game has some basic bugs that are easy enough to work around, but should have been fixed (like connecting belts is sometimes really annoying)
 - Some very basic issues when running on Linux (typical Unity stuff like launching on the wrong monitor)
 - Lack of configuration (again, can't select which monitor to run it on, I had to remove the "~/.config/unity3d/Twice Circled/Big Pharma/prefs" file before each launch to get it to start
 - Sound volume is mixed crazy poor by default (announcer voice is WAY too high, same with GUI sound effects)
 - Uninteresting and bad quality announcer voice
 - Once you get the hang of it, there is nothing 'new'. There are new ingredients and machines, but its uninteresting
 - Poor GUI design in some places, also lack of tool tips to explain things
 - Lack of insight (financials and pretty much all other numeric information is very basic) and choices (can't set medicine pricing, no realistic demand, etc - I get that some of this comes with the expansion but for a game in this genre this really should be in the base game and of high priority)
 - Limited 'base building' aspect was a huge downside for me. As a company this big I should be able to build/design my own factories
 - Quite expensive for such a basic experience (I did not pay full price, and I think this game is not worth it at the current price point. Around 10 dollars for the base game would be more realistic, dropping to 5-7 on sale)

All in all, I can not recommend this game. It was released in 2015, we're 4 years down the line and its still full of bugs and basic typo's. Unacceptable.

49058060.review:
This is a mix of a simple factorio and a tetris game.

The base of the game is closer to a geometric placement game than a management one. You get a workspace (which represents the interior of your factory) with gates (which may serve as an entry point for raw material or an exit point for pharmacetical products, according to your choice). You process raw material with machinery which every different machine has a different layout, I/Os, and every machine is linked by a conveyor belt to an other one (or to the I/O gates).
You start making the product line for a simple product, then this simple product may become an input for a more complex but profitable one, and so on.
The real limitation is that you interior space becomes more expensive as you expand, and is in fact very limited, forcing you to make choices over your product lines. I do think this is too limited to fully appreciate the game, and in my opinion is the main shortcoming of this game.

The research is not very deep, nor any other manegement part, but on another hand, a play is not supposed to last more than 2 hours. This is the perfect game if you just want to cool off steam for an evening.

The pharma industry feeling is not that strong, in the sense they could have replaced this by car industry or whatever requires an assembly line, only the graphism would have changed.

But once you know what you will get, it is a pleasing game, on which one may spend an surprising long time.

The game is well polished and works flawlessly, that is not always the case for Linux game.

By the way, there is a DLC which was shipped a few years after the game, rather thav the new machinery the new mechanics it adds is its big plus, and if you choose to acquire the game, think about the DLC.

Great game. Overall, well worth the buy for me. The overall concept is well built and thought-out, and the multiple scenarios/challenges keep this game going for a while. Replayablility is way above the normal business simulator game. 

The only drawbacks are minor things such as how marketshare doesn't totally make sense. With you and another competitor in the same drug market, you can both have 56% of the market share. If you have multiple competitors selling the same drug, a discount or decrease in price doesn't seem to help gain market share. The only other option is boosting sales rating, which is limited due to the pre-determined amount of executives. Another would be how profit and gross margin don't seem to update instantly. When a big change happens (say, firing 5 researchers) it takes multiple days for it to show on the balance sheet. Still works, but reduces the credibility of the income statement.

Although it has these drawbacks, the small graphic animations, voiced notifications, replayability, and depth of this game makes it well worth the money.

47857384.review:
This is a wonderfully made automation game entirely built around ONE mechanic. Literally everything in this game is about manipulating a number from 1-20 by increasing or decreasing it in various ways. Each machine you can build does something different; initially you get +/-1 and +/-3 machines, but then it gets to halve/double, reduce to 1, etc. The machines can be rotated but not flipped, and must have belts connecting inputs/outputs (can't be directly connected). The fact that it's all built around one core mechanic makes it absurdly simple to understand; all the little restrictions (primarily arranging machines on factory space) turns it into a deviously challenging combination of logistics and Tetris.

If you're looking for an entry to the automation game genre, or if you bounced off of something like Factorio due to its sheer complexity, then give Big Pharma a try. I am writing this having just gotten 100% of achievements after ~120 hours, so I think it's definitely worth the listed price.

45493349.review:
I have over 100 hours in this game and I think it is fantastic. I was surprised the rating is so low on this game but I figured out why - there are lots of 5 hour and under reviews that are negative. I would take these with a grain of salt as the early missions are simplistic and do not utitlize all the machines. That's like saying you mastered Starcraft because you learned how to use the beginning infantry.

Big Pharma is part logic game part puzzle game, very small part business game. If you use logic (ie, estimate the cost) to produce each drug and comapre it against the sale price you will win, assuming you can properly assess if your factory space is the correct shape/big enough to support all the machines you need to use. Then it comes down to fitting all the pieces together so the assembly line works (puzzle). Many times you will be a couple tiles short and you'll spend a lot of time trying to optimize your line so that it works.

The business sim part is less important because if you play this right the AI stands no chance against you. The AI does not figure out the best drugs so it'll always be behind you in research if you do your calculations carefully. It also does not optimize based on demand so you can just flood the market with their drugs to keep them further behind. Most of the time I just do my own thing and the let the AI do whatever it wants. If it wasn't for patents I would not even notice them.

Anyway, if you want a light logic/puzzle type of game then Big Pharma is amazing. This is the first game in a long time that kept me up late because of "one more turn." Because the results are more mathematical, it doesn't have the same kind of replayability as Sim City or the Tycoon games though. It takes more than 5 hours, but certainly less than 50 to be able to win consistantly. The different scenarious do mix it up a bit, but you will reach the point where you have "done it all." 

Overall, very much recommended!

43236299.review: Big Pharma is a game that enables you to build a successfull pharmaceutical giant from scratch in one of its many unique scenarios as well as in a sandbox or custom game. The game has a somewhat helpful tutorial and each scenario you do from beginner onward should be able to teach you the more complicated tech you will use in a full game. The game allows you to make production lines using ingredients that you sent explorers out to discover, then you use tech that you researched to produce a cure which has the most powerful effect and most unharmfull side effects. You then have to compete with other pharmaceutical companies and fight for dominance ( or to achieve your scenario goals) to be the best company. While this game is certainly one worth giving a try, it definitley has its drawbacks. For one, the complexity comes with inventing a assembly line with limited space and budget. Once you figure out an effective solution however, it is pretty much smooth sailing from their onwards. Another issue that stems from this is that the game can get very repetitive once you do find an effective cure in which case, the fast foward button becomes your friend! Overall though, the game is a good one to pass the time with here and their. I do recommend waiting for a big sale however as I did because for the price of the game, I could find some cool DLC for like, cities skylines that would probably keep me entertained for longer.

39775219.review:
Big Pharma is a sort of midpoint between a systems driven puzzle game and a management sim, and the combination works really well! It's easy to imagine a Zachtronics version of this game, where each level would be a puzzle to be optimized and solved under a set of constraints. But it has this injection of more typical Positech flow chart economics, where there's uncertain (but predictable) factors outside your control. The cure/side effect combinations are procedural, so each game has new optimal layouts to look for. I think there's a lot gonig on here, and puzzling out the best machine placements is quite fun. 

I find the theming is in somewhat an uncanny valley though. It's quite abstract and very clearly a game-y version of drug production (a handful of machines, a number based cure system, nonsensical patents, cures level up into other cures, etc), and at times sort of wants to have a humrous tone, like with the drug names. But it's also too realistic to be funny, all the diseases/conditions are real, and it blithely deals with some controversial aspects of modern healthcare. But it's not speaking to these issues really, the game doesn't have anything to *say*, it's just a theme. I wish they had leaned into the industry they were modeling in some meaningful way, or else chosen something less heavy altogether (the prime mechanic could work with anything that's produced via a process).

38986503.review:
Big Pharma is a surprisingly deep and engaging tycoon/sim type game, concealed underneath a drab and dull presentation.  It is also a game that requies a love of engineering and economics, and at times, it veers dangerously close to spreadsheet simulator territory.  Nevertheless, I have put dozens of hours into this game now, and I have enjoyed almost every minute of it -- even the times when my drug development has gotten screwed up. 

If you have played a tycoon game before, then you should understand most of the basics of Big Pharma, but there will be additional concepts to understand as well.  Your job, as the CEO of your company, is to discover ingredients, research improvements, and then build assembly lines that refine and mix ingredients into drugs.  Some of your formulations can be incredibly complicated, especially as you develop more expensive cures.  You also have to develop these cures economically, using as little equipment and space as possible.  And, finally, you have to minimize the negative side effects whenever possible, a tough task at times.  The game requires so much forethought and planning that, at times, it almost acts like a corporate chemical engineeing simulator, which is a good thing for people who love to mix building, problem solving, and economics together.  

Big Pharma does not have a ton of unique content, but it manages to stay fresh by throwing a whopping 35 scenarios at you, each with their own challenges and goals.  As a result, no two playthroughs will ever end up the same (although the early parts of the scenarios frequently play out the same).  Some of the goals that the game requires of you, especially after you get through the first twelve scenarios or so, become exceedingly difficult.  On many occasions, I have constructed what I thought was going to be the perfect assembly line, only to end up one square short of being able to place my final piece of equipment.  The game can be frustrating at these times, and it is definitely not for everyone.

As I mentioned in the opening sentence, the game's presentation is rather disappointing.  The machines and how they process the equipment looks pretty cool, but there are only a couple of music tracks that repeat themselves, ad nauseum.  The game otherwise looks quite plain and lacking in style.  At the beinning of each scenarior, you choose your avatar from a list of seven characters, but these characters have no personality and there is no perceivable difference in the gameplay between them.  Even a little bit of animation and emoting like what you find in a Sid Meier's Civilization game would have gone a long way to giving the characters some personality.  In addition, the game's marketing campaign suggests that it will provide some dark humor or satire on the questionable business practices of the pharmaceutical industry, but it never touches on this territory.  

There is a certain audience for whom Big Pharma is going to hit the mark perfectly.  Fortunately, I was one of those people.  If you have a scientific or business background and you would love to play a fun game that puts engineering and business principles to work, then this game gets a strong thumbs up from me.

38939806.review:
I have very much enjoyed this game.  It is half logistical puzzle and half management.  Trying to figure out how to make some of the more complex cures with the machines you have and in the space you have can be a challenge.  Think your doing well with millions in the bank? Well lets try to develop that cure for HIV.  Watch your millions burn up quickly as you spend it on new research and equipment grinding away at it for months if not years in the game constantly tweaking the line and then one day finally the first drug to cure HIV is sold.  Then you can jack up the price as you are the only one selling it!  It is very rewarding.  And then you have a light bulb moment and realized you can produce it for half the cost with no negative effects.  Time to rebuild the production line! 

The AI is not great, but they can become a real threat undercutting your bottom line always forcing you innovate and develop new tech and higher teer drugsif you want to survive.  

There are several different disease trees that you work through, the first drugs in the tree treating the simplest of things like soughing a cough, but as you discover more ingredients and develop better tech you can keep running that solution through higher and higher processes all the way up to creating a wonder drug that sells for thousands curing tuberculosis.  You may not always want to keep the raw formula from one to the other though as side effects and cost and become problems making you rethink everything from scratch.  

If you like solving problems, tinkering and trying to figure out how to make things always more efficient and better this is the game for you.

Honestly too much balancing the books and business, not enough making cool machines and production lines.

This is a great idea for a game, but I feel the priorities you have to keep in mind during gameplay are set up wrong. You don't just have to make drugs by combining ingredients, you have to make them CHEAPLY too; which, especially early on, often leads to situations where the most economical course of action is to just make a really simple line with 1-2 machines for cough medicine, and that's it.

Add to this a constant need to check competitors for what they're producing, what ingredients have high or low prices, what cures there is high demand for; and then you have to set prices and keep a constant eye on your sales... I found myself spending a good 70% of my time managing numbers and looking for opportunities to build a thing; which is decidely not what I want from a game like this, I want to spend my time and energy on making cool, complicated machines, that shouldn't just be a little minigame between your business management.

The fact that an hour into a game I finally made a more complex machine, and my simple cough pills I made at the start of the game easily outpaced it in income just killed all my motivation too.

35477902.review:
I want to like this game. I really do, but the gameplay gets repetitive very quickly. Add on that there are some really annoying quirks to this game, and it's not really enjoyable to play after a 15 hours. There are a ton of suggestions I'd make for this game to be more enjoyable. The biggest one is the pricing system. Dear god, I wanted to chuck my computer through a window sometimes. You have the ability to change the cost of your product, but a 2% change was enough to take you from high sales to going completely into the red. This wouldn't be such a big deal if the demand wasn't constantly changing. So one month you may have the perfect price and then three months later (even if demand for the drug is constant and no events have happened), you might be completely screwed. It's hard to build new factory lines when you have to spend 3 months watching the trends in order to get the optimal price point just to have it change on you 3 months later. I got to the point where I stopped trying, but then so many of the later campaign games have goals for total revenue over a time frame or a monthly revenue, and you're shoved back into endlessly micromanaging the price of drugs while your competitor is constantly releasing new formulas.


This was just one of MANY things that made this game frustrating at times. The drug factory formulation aspect of the game was not fun enough to stand on its own (as you see with the sandbox mode), but we weren't given the tools to make money management gameplay enjoyable or satisfying.

After repeating this a few times, I checked the community forum on steam. At the top is a sticky post on how troubleshoot if your game doesn't work. After reading through the post, I stepped through many of the instructions, toggling from the post, to my computer settings, to running the game, to having it freeze on the screen, repeat x 10. Unfortunately, none of these worked. I started a help, game doesn't work thread and after an hour or two of no feedback. I now thought I should go the game creators website (outside of steam). This was a little more tricky than it sounded, but I ultimately reached a forum page with a similiar 'sticky post' on troubleshooting. I decided I should post for help on their forum since I have received no feedback on steam. You need to register first, prior to being able to post (to prevent bots/spam). One of the safety check questions was 'What is the latest game to be released in alpha by us? After about 3 guesses with different spellings of Big Pharma, I determined that Big Pharma is not the answer. I ended up doing a bit of research on Positech (the creators of Big Pharma), I ended up doing numerous guesses of their games (and with alternate spellings of these games). I eventually guesses the correct answer, though forgot how many guesses I did, and time spent to get registered on their forum. I copied most of my steam thread and started a new thread on their forum. I have received no aid on either post its been around 24 hours, and spent 0 minutes of actual gameplay. I am now going to request a refund for my ~$5.99.

34034930.review:
I picked this game up on sale and it was definitely worth the cost. As I write this I have 26.3 hours on record and will eventually put in more.

While there are elements of games like Factorio in it in that you manage supply chains and improve production and product quality, it isn't quite so far reaching in scale. I certainly wouldn't call it shallow - I would say it's aware of scope and does a good job in terms of providing you with lots of options that have clear gameplay impact, leaning on certain puzzle elements like how you might go about making an ideal version of a product, or how you discover the next tier of products. Some unlockable traits do feel overpowered compared to others, but there are plenty of viable traits and playstyles and nothing has ever felt mandatory for winning. There are definitely some things you'll end up in the habit of doing early and similarly from game to game once you have experience, so simpler scenarios do end up feeling thin.

You can, of course, do a number of ethically dubious actions. Nothing's stopping you from continuing to ship an older version of a drug with a side effect - or from putting a premium on the side effect free version. One of the unlockable traits even requires having products recalled, and since you then have an optional benefit you can use in future games, well, that counts too I suppose. You can have sales agents greasing the works to get more patients prescribed to your drugs as well. However you're not going to find an extremely indepth take on the dark side of pharma as the majority of the focus will be the production line.

It certainly isn't a perfect game. This is one of those games where the sense of time never quite gels right. I feel like in a lot of management games you can normally reach a point where you can say "my plan for the next x units of game time is y, and the grand plan for z unit of time is such and such". I can't really tell you what a year or a month feels like in this game and it's absolutely led to me spending money far more quickly than I realized. It comes down to two reasons I think - the first is the large amount of randomization (such as ingredients and their side effects) makes a lot of long term planning impossible anyway until requisite research has been done, and you might have to change your plans if you have competitors. This is a reason I like, so I won't fault it for that. The reason I can fault is that since you spend most of your time in a factory with no humans and competition doesn't really have personality (they're mostly just some product lines and profit margins with a human avatar, really), the game can be somewhat sterile and robotic. Rather than being a pressing matter you have to remember to pay, loans will basically handle themselves (though you can pay them back early) through automatic deductions. Convenient, but it does contribute to the inability to really tell 'when' you are. Something like an annual investor meeting or elections impacting health care profits would have gone a long way to creating a sense of pacing to the game, and while events do exist that will impact drug pricing, they're random and almost never a real concern outside of very specific situations that you wouldn't find yourself in beyond the early game. The only major alleviation for this I found was to add lots of competitors so there would be things to respond to, which leads to the next hurdle the game faces.

The business side of things honestly feels very weak and I'd be hard pressed to say I ever did more than the most minor tweaks to prices, but on the other hand you can definitely do things like open up a wing that does nothing but create a mass numbers of a cheaper alternative to a competing product to try to push them out of the market. Competition may not have much personality, but it basically feels mandatory since they're one of the only things that can have a major impact on you, especially if you like long games.

The scale of the game is also sometimes a little off. If your sandbox goals are set too expansive (and you really only have two - bank x amount of cash or ship y amount of this type of drug, and you can do a "by year x" setting to add some pressure, and you can set multiple goals up) then even with a lot of things set to maximum it's entirely possible to simply run out of technology to research, ingredients to discover, land to purchase, upgrades to get, and your only option is basically to wait out the time and maybe try to develop some nonsensical super drug like a skin cream for indigestion that also treats cancer and the flu with a non-drowsy formula while waiting for money to accumulate or products to ship. Past a certain point even competition will be meaningless. The game is best experienced with more limits and competitors in place to force you to react.

It's the sort of game I play in chunks every now and then rather than a game I binge on. While sometimes awkward and definitely best if you fiddle with game settings until you discover your personal goldilocks settings, if you love the idea of optimizing a factory and production lines and stumbling upon combinations and discoveries (like finding out an otherwise unpleasant ingredient has an amazing benefit you could exploit... if you could only extract it properly), this is worth looking into. If you're looking for an indepth economics game, however, this isn't it.

If I had to give it a number rating (no decimals allowed), 7 out of 10. The flaws do stand out and can even be a little disconcerting, but I've definitely enjoyed the majority of my time.

Oh man... Big Pharma!  I find this more of a puzzle game with some minor simulation and management on the side.  The most interesting part of the core game loop for me was efficiency in space usage. 33491975.review:
This game falls into a very niche realm of the strategy genre. It blends elements of business sims, puzzle games, and even a little RTS making for a very unique experience. There are a few problems though:

-Although it has many different scenarios, they all essentially boil down to either "make money" or "make a certain type of drug"
-It is NOT worth 25 USD. I got it for around $7.50 during the summer sale and frankly that should be close to the asking price
-Since there is only one real basic principle in the game (diluting and concentrating) there isn't that much room for strategy making it a little too easy
-Unlike most games along this line, it doesn't really feel like it has the customization features that most strategy games have. Almost all of the games will feel very similar despite having different opponents/ingredients/layouts.

With all of the bad, there is a lot of good that comes with it as well:

-The game is not all that taxing on your computer. I'm able to play this on a laptop with no graphics card and I haven't experienced any lag, even with the biggest factories
-The tutorial does a fantastic job. Granted, it isn't one of those tutorials that really immerses you into the game (there's a lot of reading) but it does teach and it teaches well. I have found no problems understanding what to do and how to do it.
-The gameplay is very solid as well. Once you get the hang of the basics, it is fun to utilize the puzzle aspect of the game to make a factory that is as compact and efficient as possible
-The UI works great. It isn't customizable, but I don't care, everything is very simple and it's exactly where I expect it to be.

All in all, I would reccommend this game to anyone who loves business sims and efficiency. If you are willing to delve into its interesting mechanics, you will be rewarded with a lot of control over your factory and some great challenges when it comes to efficiency. Just be warned that the game can get a little repetitive.

32857388.review:
TLDR: I wasn't sure about this game, but it was on sale and it had a cute name so I spent the money. 
I do not regret this purchase - in fact, if I had to, I would happily pay the full price. 

The tutorials inducts you into the game mechanics without being a chore to complete, and each scenario has goals but still provides you flexibility in how you choose to accomplish them. 

Being based on "real-life" illnesses, you feel a bit of connection to the products you create. You expend time analysing the  recent hypertension compound your company's explorers discovered in the desert; using the machines at your disposal you upgrade it to diabetes medication that isn't on the market yet - you make a tidy profit for being the only supplier and you're sure there's some sufferer out there whose health has improved thanks to your work. 

The difficulty level ratchets up as you play: it is never too hard but time restrictions keep you focused on your goals. 

Mechanically, there is a lot to do to keep you from getting bored: research new technology, send explorers out to gather new compounds, analyse the market for drugs, compare yourself to your competitors (and aim to keep ahead of them), respond to market/consumption changes, and (most importantly) create and develop pharmaceuticals. 

There are also a lot of decisions to make and the "right choice" is not always clear. Do you spend capital and reduce profits to remove a negative side-effect from a new medication? The answer to that question changes based on your unique situation. How much will it cost? Is the market competitive or do you have a monopoly? How much less will people pay for their cough medicine if there's a small chance they will get a rash from it? 

The only improvement I would make to this game is adding more variable challenges. This exists somewhat in the Global Events mechanism - random policy changes outside your control which alters in-game values. For example, a new mental health policy might increase demand for antidepressants. Additionally, competitors sometimes patent a product you're already producing which can be a big shock to your profit margins and production lines. However, there could be more challenges in this sense.

32164187.review:
This game is fun for a few hours, but it gets boring and repetitive fairly quickly.

The game description is very misleading. "As the head of your own Pharmaceutical Conglomerate you have this power resting in your hands. Will you use it for good?"

You don't really have any choice in this matter. You can't set the price of the drugs you make, each one has an intrisic value that honestly doesn't change much despite various in-game events. Really the only somewhat interesting thing that can happen to force you to react to the market is if another competitor patents a drug you're making so you have to tweak it a bit to get around the patent.

Making drugs has been oversimplified given that you magically know what you have to do to upgrade each cure to the next level. The only puzzle aspect is setting up your factory, and the only real difficulty there comes from the small building layouts, poor conveyor routing (you can't build stacked conveyors), and strangely shaped machines with inconvenient input and output locations. You can't plan out layouts in advance, you buy the machines/conveyors immediately and if it doesn't work or you made a mistake, then you've wasted money.

This game isn't particularly difficult and is fun for a few hours, but has no real depth to it. I did the tutorial, did the beginner challenge, jumped straight to the advanced challenge, and then used the sandbox to build the ultimate assembly line to make the ultimate drug. In doing that, I feel like I've seen everything this game has to offer.

I got this as part of a bundle for dirt cheap, and for that price it was worth it, but I'm honestly shocked at the retail price of this game. Given the shallow gameplay and general lack of content, I can't recommend this at the price they're asking.

31917680.review:
A game that reminds of the great Theme Hospital but sadly is not one - although it is not a bad game in itself.

Big Pharma is a game about drug production by setting up processing lines that change different ingredients into a drug that can be sold with profit. You get a number of machines that can change the drug intensity, upgrade it or remove side affects that come along. Each steps of course comes with a price and it's up to you judge if you want a better drug or make more money on it - sometimes both means the same but not always.

The visual aspect and general user interface are really great. A bit old school but well designed and look.

The processing line design is pretty fun - I must admit. In general it's a puzzle - place more cheaper machines that takes less space or more costly ones that do the job for three but at higher cost. Either way you have to judge space requirement over probable income loss. Depending on the drug complexity the processing lines can be quite long and interesting and putting them up together is the meat of the game. You need to watch for side effects, adjust proper concentration, mix them together to combine certain effects in order to upgrade them. The whole marketing model is quite complex and opponents do put up a fight. 

Apart from that you get scientists you can hire in order to discover more complex machines and other enhancements. You also get to hire people to discover other ingredients curing different diseases. They're costly so you need to manage this as well.

There are some issues though - ones that really spoil a lot of the fun. First of while the theme is interesting it causes the names to be hard to remember. This goes especially for ingredient names and diseases treated - I could not remember them whatsoever and had to constantly check by hovering over or visiting cures screen. Fact that processed drugs at each stage look almost the same - apart from the small distinction in colour does not help at all. The machine names are easier to remember but just a little. Also the fact that once you research Creamer there is no point in shipping pills is also off putting.

But the worst offence was a combination of trying to optimize the output combined with competition. The game gives you a packaging machine. This enables storing multiple drugs in a single package, thus the packages contain more but are less frequently occupying the conveyor belt. This lets you output multiple drugs into a single slot. The number of slot is limited and you can use them both for input and output - thus makes sense to have 4 inputs and single output - and is doable. However if your opponent gets a patent on one of the drugs you're producing you are screwed. The forbidden drug will stop the export and halt all four lines to a point in which you have to manually delete and replace the conveyor belt in order to get your other lines working. Really annoying and proves that optimizing this area is pointless.

Overall apart from the problems noted the game is pretty good. Has it's flaws but did enjoy it. Though probably will not get back to it again.

31366225.review:
I have spent many hours playing this game learning what it's about. so lets get the negative stuff out of the way. 

Cons: 

A bit expensive for what it is
No multiplayer options.
Tooltips can be vague and require testing in game to discover how to use machines.

I think its a great game for what it is. A singleplayer Business simulator with several puzzle mechanics. I felt it was complicated enough to be interesting yet simple enough that most people could take the time to learn the game and play it if they enjoy this type of game. I felt it was a bit expensive for the type of game with no multiplayer support.  I got it on sale and felt that $15 dollar price I paid was a bit more appropriate. 

I think this game could have had more fun added by competing agianst friends, instead you compete against AI's which can think a million times faster than you do, at least there is a pause feature to give you a chance to compete. 

To my final point, I spent lots of time searching and testing the equipment to learn what they did exactly and the impacts of using each equipment type. It wasn't very apparent with the tool tips but after using them and doing some digging they start to make more sense. 

Pros: 
Fun puzzle mechanic and timing mechanic for both equipment, belt, Packaging, and ingredient placing. 
Interesting puzzle mechanic in developing drugs and tradoffs. 
Interesting business mechanics like patents and such (part of the expansion I believe).
Feels like you are really making some interesting business decisions with the "Risk vs. Reward"

I found this game very enjoyable, I have put 60+ hours into the game at this point, I suspect I will be putting in more time.

This is probably one of my favorite games ever.

Hace un año que Big Pharma comenzó a desarrollar sus medicamentos por todo el mundo, y tanto ha sido su éxito que desde ahora lo tenemos disponible en castellano.

Seguro que muchos de vosotros no conocíais este juego, yo misma me sorprendido al saber de él, eso sí, cuando comencé a jugar al juego, vi como pasaban las horas y horas en el reloj mientras creaba mis fábricas y medicamentos para todo el mundo.

El tema que nos trae el juego parece aburrido a simple vista, porque gestionar una empresa farmacéutica no parece que ser un trending topic en los géneros de los videojuegos, pero por eso mismo hueco que hay ha sido bien aprovechado con Big Pharma. El juego está diseñado de tal manera que será entretenido a la vez que adictivo, brindándonos una experiencia muy satisfactoria. 

Big Pharma  es un juego de simulación y estrategia, en el cual desempeñaremos el papel de dueño y señor de nuestra propia farmacéutica, donde fabricaremos remedios para las diferentes enfermedades.

El comienzo no será del todo sencillo porque el tutorial que nos encontramos no es de los mejores que he visto, haciendo un poco pesado en algunos momentos, aunque una vez terminado la cosa se pondrá un poco más a nuestro favor.

Las misiones son interesante, encontrándonos a veces en la bancarrota, e incluso con un tiempo determinado recaudar el dinero necesario para salir victorisos, y muchas de las veces a toda costa, sin importar realmente el resultado en el consumidor.

Un consejo es que penséis bien la organización de las máquinas para fabricar los medicamentos porque los espacios son limitados y en muchas ocasiones nos encontraremos con situaciones en las que nos arrepentiremos de cómo están o que quisiéramos más metros para ampliar la empresa. Si es verdad que podremos reubicarlas, y algo es algo porque si no sería un completo caos.

No solo de fabricar se trata el juego. Antes de fabricar algo nuevo, habrá que innovar, desde buscar nuevos ingredientes hasta disponer de máquinas punteras que nos sean de utilidad para fabricar esos nuevos medicamentos que necesitamos.

En ciertas ocasiones nos dará a pensar cómo funcionan realmente las farmacéuticas en la realidad, aunque no nos confirma nada por supuesto, pero a más de uno,  después de unas cuantas partidas se lo pensará dos veces eso de ir a la farmacia a comprar un medicamente tan simple como un paracetamol. ¿Y esto porque? Creamos medicamentos que solventen problemas, los mejoraremos añadiendo ciertos ingredientes para ser más potentes y dar mejores resultado, pero… llegan los efectos secundarios. Estas cosas hacen que los consumidores puedan no comprar estos medicamentos por miedo a lo que pueda pasar. Si queremos inflar nuestro bolsillo nos pensaremos si mejorar nuestro producto, o dejarlo como estaba y seguir ganando más pelas, pero claro, a consecuencia de que los más enfermos no consigan curarse.

Para concluir, y para daros un alegría final. Podemos confirmaros que el juego esta en castellano, todos los textos, y todas las opciones del juego que están traducidas a nuestro idioma, y es una buena noticia porque si ello sería un poco costoso seguir el hilo de todo para los hispano hablantes.

Big Pharma nos ha gustado, es un original simulador con toques arcade de manera que equilibra el entretenimiento con las funciones de empresario dueño de una farmacéutica. Mejorable en algunos aspectos como los gráficos, pero le perdonaremos por llegarnos por fin en castellano. 

Más en: creativefuturegames(doc)com

30342990.review:
Un juego de gestión de lineas de producción ambientado en el mundo de las farmacéuticas: Obtenemos ingredientes básicos y hemos de ir modificando sus propiedades a base de procesarlos en máquinas, mezclarlos con otros, etc. hasta obtener un medicamento con un buen equilibrio entre coste de producción y eficacia de la cura/efectos secundarios.

El tutorial es largo pero bien llevado y deja todo bastante claro, por lo que aunque el juego puede resultar un poco confuso al principio, enseguida se le pilla el truco. El problema recae en que el juego en sí, la verdad, no me resultó muy divertido: Crear las lineas de producción es laborioso, no sólo por las máquinas que hay que usar, sino por la disposición en la fábrica (cada máquina tiene entradas y salidas cuya posición/orientación es diferente), lo que obliga a andar reposicionando todo bastante más de lo que se debería.

La investigación de nuevos ingredientes/máquinas es demasiado simple y no añaden muchas cosas nuevas al proceso, con lo que enseguida se convierte en más de lo mismo de un proceso que resulta tedioso.

No veo muy claro qué es lo que necesita el juego, pero creo que objetivos a más corto plazo que el genérico "obtén 1 millón de dólares en dos años" podría funcionar, dándonos metas más concretas del estilo "haz un medicamento para el Insomnio más eficaz que el de tu competidor". También estaría bien poder jugar con los precios de los medicamentos (el precio es automático dependiendo del medicamento e inmodificable), por darle algo más de juego al tema financiero.

En resumen, un juego que es un poco cometiempos pero que en general resulta tedioso y poco interesante.

Completados: Tutorial y primera misión.

30339893.review:
Choosing to recommend this game or not was kind of a dilemma to me. I ended up giving it a positive recommendation, but I'd like to show the pro's and cons so you can weigh it for yourself if you're considering to buy the game.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*]Mixing up medicine, having to consider side effect and processing costs is actually a lot of fun
[*]Has a "Theme Hospital" vibe which is fun!
[*]Lots of challenging levels that you can complete at Beginner, Advanced or Master level. Difficulty felt just right!
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]No multiplayer
[*]There are these "competitors" who you can't see or hear much about, only that they are working on the same market as you and, of course, against you. I'd love to have seen their companies too!
[*]Progression felt rather shallow; there aren't many machines to use. You can combine a lot however which is great, but perfecting medicine often results in high processing costs, making your drug unprofitable which is stopping you from making awesomely thought out layouts.
[*]At it's current price-point, there's not enough the game has to offer. 
[/list]

I really enjoyed this game, but at some point I had the feeling of "Ok, well this is it" and hit a wall when I couldn't really progress any further. The game's various levels really do put up a good effort to delay that feeling though and it definitely improves replayability, but to me that didn't feel like a strong enough reason to keep playing. I feel that a game like Factorio would be a better choice for a comparable game. Big Pharma is definitely fun while it lasts, so consider getting it in sale; I'd value it at about 10 bucks.

Was this review useful to you? [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26849460/]Please also check out the Izzy Reviews Curator page[/url] for regular updates on reviews for other games!

29514250.review:
When I was still new to Steam, I ran across Big Pharma on sale and thought "okay, looks interesting, I'll get it." Paid my money, downloaded my copy, and...well...forgot about it. Then, a day or so ago, I decided to give it a try after all.

I really wish I'd done so earlier.

Okay, so here's the deal. Big Pharma is part business sim, part process puzzle. It's important that you recognize this duality, because unless you like both, you may not enjoy yourself. Pure business sims like Capitalism of days gone by focus on acquisition of materials, production of product, marketing and sales, but they ignore the mechanics of actually making those products; it's a black box where inputs go in and outputs come out. On the flip side, process puzzles like Space Chem (which I truly enjoy) or Factorio place the emphasis on how you're going to make something and naught else. Big Pharma is what you get when you combine those two. Maybe a little heavy on the process side. In BiPh, you're running a pharmaceutical plant (surprise, right?) and you need to make useful products. You'll be adjusting concentrations to activate and deactivate ingredients' properties, purifying compounds, combining ingredients, and basically performing gymnastics to produce a drug that will, for example, treat angina without having your patients firing diarrhea all over the place or something even worse. 

The nifty bit is that you can be a ruthless pharmaschmuck who doesn't really care about the product so long as it makes money. If you're content to market a painkiller that causes nightmares, swelling, and anal leakage, you can. But you can also go the three extra miles to make a drug that cures Alzheimer's, is fast-acting, and non-drowsy. It's all down to A) how you want to run the business, and B) how creative you can be in getting your production lines to work. You need to feed your inputs into specific machinery in specific orders to do what you want, and that means that you're also playing a path puzzle game. BiPh is three games in one tidy, creative, attractive package.

Graphics are good, plenty good for the purpose, and even include customization options. Play is as flexible as you want to be, as detailed and difficult as you want it to be. Replay value? You bet; you'll learn something new all the time, mostly better ways to do the same thing. Music is enjoyable. And perhaps most importantly - it's fun. 

Plus, they were good enough to include a Freebuild mode, so you can experiment to your heart's content. Major plus in my book.

As for negatives, there are very few, mainly orbiting the sphere of "not-quite-intuitive." There will be times where you set up a complex production line that SHOULD be producing the Wonderdrug Of All Time but is instead turning out what amounts to Kool-Aid. Then you'll find out you had a mixer set backwards and it was combining inputs wrong. And you'll get annoyed and have to purge the line before getting things going again. But some philosophers argue that frustrations are the lessons we learn best. Clearly, these people needed a day job because they had way too much time on their hands. However, as you build up your experience, you'll make these mistakes less and less often, your production lines will become more efficient, and you'll inflict nuclear incontinence on fewer people who take your meds.

The multi-part tutorial is complete and easy to follow. You can also use it repeatedly to reference parts that seem to have gone wrong for you; I did. There's also a nice wiki community supporting BiPh, and the developer seems like an honestly decent sort, the kind of dev you want to support. And as if all this wasn't enough, BiPh was deliberately designed to be moddable! If there's more you can ask for...you might be bordering on getting greedy.

At the end of the day (and beginning and middle), this one has my thumbs pointing up. There's a lot of fun to be had here. Just don't make my mistake - play it as soon as you pick it up. You won't regret it.
