In general, I like Big Pharma, and have had fun completing some of the various challenges. The initial puzzle solving is interesting, and I enjoy trying to create the perfect drug in the space allotted. I also very much like that it is pauseable real-time, so that I can take as long as I want figuring things out.

However, the game is very similar each play-through, with only minor randomness (the floor layout and the ingredients list are all that change). So once you know what works, it pretty much works every time. The computer opponents are also not so much competitors as a nuisance, as they cannot beat you, but only get in your way. The only thing you are really fighting against is the clock, and your own goals.

So while I think this game is good for people who like puzzle and optimization games, it is not for everyone, I am not sure it is worth the full asking price. So if this looks interesting to you, watch for a good sale and give it a try.

29379815.review:
Big Pharma isn't a bad game, but I just didn't have much fun with it. It seems like a game designed for someone who is a little OCD and enjoys the process of meticulously optimizing a production line. For me, the game kept me engaged but felt more like work than fun.

Pros:
+ The game looks good and is pretty polished.
+ The mechanics are fine and sensible. The game is very playable.
+ The game does require a lot of strategy. There is a definite puzzle element that might appeal to some people.

Cons:
- If you want to go beyond simple competence in the game, it requires some heavy-duty number crunching and space optimization. This feels like a game where the right way to play it would involve lots of spreadsheets and things.
- The game lacks a story or structure to keep it engaging. You work hard to meet a meaningless goal. Then, once you finally beat a level, your work was for nothing and you just go to the next level--which is pretty much the same as the one before it. I did not find the payoff for my hard work to be worth it.

I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a little bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total disappointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!

The review will be constructed into 5 parts:
1. Game description (from what I’ve seen in the time I’ve played).
2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.
3. Pros/Cons.
4. Final thoughts.
5. Rating

So let's begin...

1. Game description:

When I started this game I had expected something like Roller coaster tycoon(what I think a management game should be) but with medical drugs. I was so wrong.
 The graphics are on par for a management game. Nothing too special but not bad. Music and sound effects are ok and the gameplay is…well OK too. It’s nothing special and definitely not what I expected, but it’s OK for what it does. However the building part doesn’t matter too much and that’s what killed it for me. It’s a micromanagement decision making game, with a little construction thrown in.

2. Did i finish the game? NO

The fact that the building portion of the game was so small made me uninstall it after the first mission. I don’t think I will be coming back to this one.

3. Pros/Cons.

PROS:
- A pretty good management game

CONS:
- Not a lot of building in it

4. Final thoughts:

Not my style of management game, although a lot of people will enjoy it. 

5. Rating

6/10

What are you looking for when looking at this game?

A simulator that has some strategy elements? Check.
A simple logic game that explores, albeit superficially, the market dynamics of drug development? Okay.
A game where the computer can beat you if you aren't paying attention? Done. (We all know games are much easier than they use to be)

You'll be satisfied enough, especially if you get it on-sale. The game touches on aspects of the pharmaceutical industry. No, you can't be as evil as you'd like, but the DLC can allow you to be fairly evil. Someone said something in their review about no price adjustment...you CAN price adjust if you have the DLC and patent your drugs. Just like real life.

There isn't the ethical dilemmas that really exist in real life, but those would be hard to replicate anyway without actually having a more human element to the game. Maybe in the future when AI becomes more relevant in video games you might be able to create an irrational element to it, but as of now it's just a computer buying your product following programming that tells it how to behave.

It's simple enough to be fun and has enough depth to be interesting. 

P.S. had to mention that treating a disease is less profitable than curing it. It's economics. Someone said it and their ignorance hurt. On that note, you can create cures and treatments in this game. They don't always affect each other.

Demasiado complejo para mí . Todo consiste en tomar una materia prima , que tiene un "valor" en unidades curativas , y a traves de manipulaciones en maquinas , convertirlo en un medicamento , con un "valor" distinto.

El temas se complica por la existencia de varias materias primas , con "valor" distinto,  y porque en ocasiones , para conseguir el medicamento objetivo , primero has de fabricar otros varios medicamentos , para acabar fusionandolos , teniendo que hacer una cantidad terrible de modificaciones en los "valores" de todos ellos. 28277824.review:
A superbly cerebral challenge. While it can be daunting at first, as the game throws machines, ingredients, concentration and catalyst mechanics at you, then pours a layer of supply/demand economics on top of it, this game handily avoids a lot of the pitfalls of more traditional economic management sims & city builders. This is primarily because the ingredients, catalysts and cure upgrades are all randomised. So there is no single "best layout" that works in every map for every challenge. You aren't simply creating 2 farms, 2 mills, 1 bakery, in the tightest formation allowed. 

Instead, you spent a lot of your time looking at potential cures, looking at the ingredients that lead to it, and working out whether the end product might be worth trying to create the production line for it. Then it's down to arranging the machines in such a way as to produce the product. Mistakes happen early and often, but you get the hang of it with enough practice. 

The research and development arms of the game give a real sense of progression as you open up new options for cures and expansion. Finally, you have to make sure you're not oversaturating the market between your own products and your competitors. 

It's loads of fun and every bit of complexity is well placed to make for interesting, challenging decisions.

28192568.review:
[h1] Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Simulator[/h1]
https://youtu.be/xsVVcTnd9s8
+ The gameplay is extremely addicting. Basically you are building a lab full of assembly lines that take raw ingredients and converts them into medicine or pills to sell for profit.
+  Visually the game looks great with a very nice clean charming style. Once you build a bunch of machines it can be very entertaining to just sit back and watch your factory essentially print money.
+ A lot of strategy and planning is involved while designing your machines. You will often have to move around or completely change a line to develop an even greater product. Every machine has a different entry and exit point, so you really have to keep in mind how much space you have, and try to make things compact.
+ Surprisingly complex. I found the game to be a tad hard to learn at first, but once you grasp the concept it will feel very rewarding as you learn how to upgrade and mix ingredients to form greater level cures.
+ A LOAD of content. If you plan on beating the game I'm sure you can spend over 40 hours easily as each level is quite time consuming. (which is not a bad thing)

- The tutorials were very lengthly and a bit tedius to get through as they have you read through a bunch of instructions rather than introducing the mechanics in a more fun way. (A narrator could have helped)
- There isn't any information that tells you the supply / demand for each type of drug. Therefor, you do not really have any idea what a new drug will sell for. I'd often find myself spending quite a bit upgrading an assembly line to make a higher tier medication only to find out that the new medication was not selling for much and there's no way I could have known.

UPDATED REVIEW:

I initially gave this game a negative review due to the incredible difficulty. There is an extreme learning curve here, at least for me. It took me a solid 10 hours of gameplay before I finally figured out how to complete even the 2nd beginner scenario. I will admit that I rage-quit several different times before finally getting the hang of it. Therefore, if you have little to no patience (like me), beware. 

This isn't the best game ever made, but it also isn't the worst. It isn't your typical "tycoon" game, as it requires a LOT more thought and strategy. I still wish there was a difficulty slider so wimpy me could make it a bit easier, but I would have to say that I have enjoyed my time playing. I sitll dislike that luck determines what ingredients you start off with, but I suppose this allows for a bit of replayability as no two scenarios are ever quite the same. 

All in all, I would recommend this game, but only on sale. The standard price seems a bit steep for what this game has to offer.

This is a puzzle/logistics game that dives into the economy/politics side of drug companies.  There are various challenges to complete, with different tiers of success, ensuring you will come back to previous challenges with more experience and a better outcome.  Some examples of challenges include, deliver 200 units of hair loss product (requiring desert research and follow-up exploration and an end-game atomic sequencer) before a set amount of time, produce 6 products with a B+ rating (you can make a few extra bucks if you don't process out side-effects, but this challenge requires you to find profitable and sustainable drugs without using questionable business practices), and make as much money as possible using patents, putting out as much product with as little work as possible, and undercutting the AI businesses as much as possible!

This game's business side is a little light, but is expanded on in the very affordable DLC that add new layers to the game.  I would recommend getting the DLC, but only after you try the base game.  It isn't everyone's cup of tea, but it sure is mine!

Business

26088217.review:
https://gamejudges.wordpress.com/2016/10/17/big-pharma/
Big Pharma is a strategy/puzzle game and an assembly line simulator, in which you’re tasked with manufacturing and selling pharmaceuticals. You are creating drugs by altering the concentrations up or down each step requiring a machine with a line in and out. The raw materials and finished drug need an exit from the game. You research new materials and upgrades to your operation and apply for patents before your competitors do. Each material has a density from 0 to 20. Effects and side-effects apply to a segment of the density scale. The game is sufficiently complex without the expansion, which adds setting prices for meds and real competition.

Verdict:
The game is complex and surprisingly fun to play. The expansion is too complex IMO and not much fun since it’s too hard. It’s worth a buy, but save yourself a lot of grief and stick with the vanilla version.

I had a ton of fun playing this game. The drug industry theme is very unique and refreshing. 25828910.review:
Big Pharma could be characterized as a procedural logic puzzle game with several random-ish elements.

But that sounded a bit boring, so I'd rather call it a "living puzzle".

Basically you got your factory gadgets, which need to face certain directions, and you connect them to each other with conveyor belts. Then you input drug ingredients from wall sockets and upgrade them along the production line. You can rotate the gadgets, but not mirror them. After you decide your production line is long enough and your drug is done, it must be processed into a pill, a cream etc. and sent back into a wall socket - then you can begin selling it!

It's not a simple as it sounds, in fact I think this game is quite challenging, at least with the DLC add-on. Some people said that the base game is a bit easy, but I only played with the DLC. Every factory gadget has a processing cost when stuff moves through it. So you have to ensure your drug is cheap to make by optimizing the amount of gadgets. You can make your drug stronger and boost your sales by getting rid of side-effects or adding positive effects and boosters from other ingredients, but there are many specific logical rules in place which ensure that you will mostly have a hard time doing so.

After playing a while I have to say I like this game. Somehow it balances the line between being both addictive and frustrating at the same time. The game is quite well made and balanced gameplay-wise, and I've yet to see any bugs in the game which is also a very good sign.

25822575.review:

25789731.review:
Pretty good game!

This is a rare gem of puzzle strategy capitalistic game! Yeah i know, quite a bizarre genre but loads of fun!

[list]
 [*] In this game, you own a pharmaceutical company with a bit of cash and you need to setup a production chain of one or more medicines. 
To do that, you start with some space in a factory to setup your production line with the machines and conveyor belts.
You feed the first machine an ingredient with a wanted effects (and lots of unwanted side effects! ;-) and by transforming that initial ingredient in each machine, you can remove the side effects, strenghten the good effect and even upgrade the good effect to something even better! (That you can sell for more money of course!)
 [*] The game is pretty easy to learn to play and there are 6 well made tutorials to make you learn, but it is quite a challenge to master! Every game is different, there are many ingredients to create your medicine and you can even combine ingredient to add many effects, the sky is the limit!
 [*] You also got researchers and explorers to discover/improve your machines and to discover new ingredients around the world!
 [*] You have ai competitors who can make the same medicine as you and undercut you, which makes you poor pretty fast, so you must watch how well your medicines sell all the time! And the ai is not dumb, pretty smart and scary sometimes in the higher difficulty levels!
 [*] The game is pretty stable. I didn't have any crash or any annoying bug for that matter. Actually, the game is bug free from the whole time i played, which is quite something nowaday in non-finished rushed to market games of today.
 [*] The pricing is adequate. In the 20$ which is good for a game that well made and with a lot of hours of fun to have.
[/list]

Enjoyable game which takes more thought than you anticipate. 

The tutorial type levels are nice and easy and give perfect direction upon how to play the game. From there I feel the learning curve is a satisfying one. It caters to people of different aptitude by having different levels of completion. 

I find this game is best for killing some time especially when you may need to quit to do something else at any time (like being on call for example) as you can pause and save any time and you can really burn a lot of time on it without realising. 

The only problem I have had is in the higher levels when you have a lot of processes going on. It  is more intensive on the PC than I had imagined. 25738615.review:
A rather okay game. An interesting idea and a complex idea. The good: it has some real science behind it, though obviously not even near 100% correct. But for the point of the game, you can ignore it. The challenges are in fact challenges. It's not an easy game. You'll have to plan a bit.  I enjoyed parts of it but you can't play too long or you'll burn out. I wish I could better explain it.

Good:
>You'll have fun many times
>It's not easy, it's a challenge so you'll be entertained
>Good music
>Careful planning is rewarded
>Addictive


Bad:
>The beginning of each challenge is near identical as you have to restart learning the same techniques; but the parts that change are the ingredients. Based on luck. If lucky, it's easy. If not, prepare your anus.
>Some things seem utterly random , such as which side effect is on each ingredient
>Some effects contradict themselves
>You will be in debt a lot. No idea how people hit the 600$ daily when I can do at best 200$ when being careful (this is on EASY by the way). I constantly was close to meeting an objective, just waiting for a new loan
>Competition nearly never does anything BUT when they do, they do in fact screw you over
>Something is off with the economics. I have a superior product (cure and sales rating), no side effects and it ISN'T dominating the market... when the only other one is a weaker, side effect ridden competition drug. How???

Neutral:
>There's a learning curve so take time to learn. 
>The tutorials aren't too easy to follow, so pay attention

That's about it. It's a game that you play a challenge and once done, you take a break. Come back the next day. 
Advice: Beat the tutorial. Free build is nice to test out things (a good idea, especially about combining ingredients), but is utterly boring to play in. Custom build might be better if you want to practice techniques for challenges. It gives you the ability to learn how to properly research, search for ingredients, deal with money, etc, WITHOUT being restricted.

So again: Free build if you wanna quickly try out how to combine things or how equipment works. But use custom build to practice for challenges. The challenges can be very hard and very easy.  The game is rough but fun, but very exhausting. It's not the greatest but it does the job. It could learn from other games like Rollercoaster tycoon.

25724862.review:
This game is one of my best recent purchases. I got this at 66% off, but 21 hours in, I can definitely say it is worth full price.

I completed the tutorials in about 90 minutes, and it has taken me a further 20 hours to beat all the beginner levels to Master standard.

I've just moved up to Intermediate level, and discovered that there are a whole load of new machines and research topics, plus more cures, ingredients, side-effects, and ways to combine them together! I wasn't expecting such a leap in complexity, and I still have not checked out the Advanced levels yet! I've also noticed, that many of the achievements seem interesting, and might be worth pursuing in their own right.

Before purchasing. I read some of the negative reviews, which mentioned the randomness of the game, and repetitive nature of the gameplay. Sure, some of it is repetitive; when starting a new level, you have to build up your factory and income, but the randomness is a good thing - in different games, different ingredients lead to different cures and side-effects, and you have to combine them in different combinations. You have to think - you can't just keep repeating the same cures you developed in previous games. In my view, that's a very good thing!

There are so many aspects of this game, and it is much deeper than I expected. I've yet to unlock and discover all the elements of the game, but already I can see the potential for creating super drugs which cure multiple illnesses at once, and could potentially be worth thousands of dollars. That kind of drug won't be easy to create, but is definitely doable if you make the right combinations.

Do yourself a favour, and just buy it!

25710767.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Big Pharma is a game developed by Twice Circled and published by Positech Games, the same people behind Gratuitous Space Battles' series, Gratuitous Tank Battles and the Democracy series

Big Pharma throws you into the medicinal making business where you run a pharmacuetical company distributing drugs that help people whilst also making big green dollar bills. The game is both a management simulation game and also surprisingly a bit of a puzzle game

To create a drug you first have to find the suitable ingredients, each ingredient comes with a cure, a side effect and sometimes a booster (these are usually found in other ingredients and not the same one). Through that you then can make you're drug by processing it through machinery that can mix and match to evenly balance both the cure and the side effects

The game is fun yet challenging at the same time, and with the constant upgrades you can make more and more drugs which then can be sold on the market

However, the game can get repetitive and some points and it does have a steep learning curve to master the game which can put some people off, you don't have to play it the correct way (which is what free build offers you), however, it is interesting to play how the game wants you to play

Big Pharma is not for everyone, me personally, I enjoy it when I play it in short bursts, however, the game is not for everyone...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

25709831.review:
This isn't really a tycoon game, which it may look like from the screenshots. No, this is a production optimization game in the same vein as Factorio, where space and time are your limiting resources, and your goal is to build complex production lines as efficiently as possible. And that doesn't always mean using the biggest machines: speed of production and floor space sometimes seem to require the smaller machines, while more effective (or bigger-money!) cures, or profitability concerns, may require the less time-efficient but more step-efficient larger machines.

So, if you think you'll enjoy laying out machines and tweaking your layouts for the best outcome, this is for you.

25685073.review:
Overall, I had fun with the game. Nothing exposes your inner evil than becoming a pharmaceutical executive. The gameplay is not too complex, mostly based around creating production lines increasing and decreasing concentration or adding new ingredients to reach the higher tier drugs or to add special effects. Building machinery is similar to tetris: rotate the fixed input and output points until the shortest connection between them is possible or they take up the least amount of place.

Few issues:
- Most maps are badly designed, as a result of the tetris-like elements. Buildings are oddly shaped, full of narrow passages and corridors that make placing fixed sized and shaped machines frustrating or requiring a lot of moving around. I would personally prefer a more Prison Architect style gameplay where I can freely design buildings to suit my needs.
- Just as real medical research, I assume, production lines involve certain amount of rial and error. Some machines remove some effects, but so far I found no explanation for that. The mixers lack labeling on input, so the first mix is a trial and error in determining what will be the base and what the additive.
- The upgrade system is uninspiring. Purely decrease the operating cost of a machine by x amount of money. No tech to increase speed, improve supply, or anything more meaningful. A deeper, more diverse research system would be nice.
- The AI does weird things. I developed Drug A. Cornered the market to 90%. The AI developed Drug B, a less effective version of Drug A. Got the 10%. So far so good. But over time, based on its less effective drug, with a higher price tag and a lower sales rating, it managed to muscle me out of the whole market with no rational explanation.
- The patent system is ridiculous and broken, just like in real life I guess. I have been selling a drug I developed ahead of the competitors for 10 years. Then the AI slaps a patent on it, and retroactively pulls mine off the market. That would be like me patenting apples and hitting all fruit farmers with a cease and desist letter which there is no recourse for. It is an unfair, broken and gimmicky system that should not be in the game in its current form. Drugs already on the market should not be subject to the system, it should be an option once you developed a new drug.

In conclusion, I do not regret my purchase. The game is fun albeit simplistic and sometimes a bit rough around the edges. It is still an entertaining management game. With some additional elements a sequel to it could be a really good game.

25656701.review:
Big Pharma is an interesting game. You run a pharmasuitical company, who's goal is to simply make products to cure what ails your customers. You research new tools, machines, and send forth expeditions to the far corners of the globe in search of strange components.

I strongly suggest Big Pharma if you enjoy any of the following: automation, strange scenarios, medicine, or building a global medicine empire. This game is a strange sort of fun, and I find it oddly relaxing to play when stressed out. Combining different materials into one super drug is oddly satisfying, and selling products that may have flaws isn't a horrible thing to do. Even the oddest combination of cures can be an effective medicine, like depression and heart attack meds as one pill or cream. It sells well, but may cause irritated skin.

Big Pharma is a strange game, but a great game overall. Give it a try, and see how well you can manage a pharmasuitical business.

25642895.review:
280 Hours on the game... half which I was probably afk...

Where to Start... 

It's a decent game. The graphics are clean. The user interface is pretty straight forward. It's entertaining. It has a good tutorial. There are a few metrics of the game that are a bit tricky, but once you figure it all out, you can start pumping out money making products in no time. The only real issue i have with the game is it's a bit repetitive after a while. The only real reason I’m still playing it, mainly to finish off the last achievement I need for a perfect game. 

The grind is always the start of the level. All the challenges with the exception of the full unlock mission, have everything locked up tight. It's a bit annoying to have to go thru the same unlock everything BS each time you start a new level. Other games would let you unlock it, and then allow you to keep it on future missions, not this game.

The other real issue with this game is the luck generation. A level is never hard or easy based on your skill or the conditions of the level.... The level is hard or easy based on the ingredients it gives you. If you get great ingredients, you can have a great start and plow through the level pretty easily. If you get shit ingredients, it’s just a long drag and struggle and you're better off starting over and hoping for a better starting hand. 

The game's full price is about $30 CDN. I'm notoriously cheap when it comes to buying games, not because I don’t appreciate the cost of development, but because I have about 500 games on my steam account I haven’t touched yet. It makes it harder to buy a new game over playing something I already bought and paid for. 

The moment I saw Big Pharma, i knew i wanted to buy it, but not at full pop. However, it is currently on sale for $10 CDN. Is it worth that, I would say yes. 

I figured i got a solid 100 hours of entertainment from this game, so at $0.10 / hour, this game is a great steal at $10. 

Even if you tried it and found yourself bored after about 20 hours, it's hard to be entertained in this world for $0.50 / hour. 

Do I recommend it?? 
I recommend buying this game when it's on sale.
I'd give it a solid 7/10

24784527.review:
Big Pharma is a combination of tycoon sim, Tetris, and puzzle game.

The tycoon sim part is basic; you try to make sure your profits are higher than your expenses, you take out a loan if you're low on cash, you supply more of the drugs that are high in demand, and so on. The simple business management aspect suits the game well.

The Tetris part comes from the unique shape of the machines you place in your factory lines and the limited space in which you have to use. In the early game your available space is small, in the late game your factory lines are complex and long, and in both cases maximizing the use of space for optimal output is important. 

The puzzle part is the meatiest: drug ingredients have components (with negative or positive effects) which can be removed, upgraded, or swapped around using one of your machines. These all have active ranges that vary, and it takes a bit of mental arithmetic to find the sweet spots to create the drug of your choice.

When creating drugs, all three parts of the game come into play, making Big Pharma a game with depth and replayability. The campaign missions start you off in an empty factory, which makes gameplay fairly repetitive (though getting randomly generated ingredients and starting ingredients mitigates this somewhat). If you don't mind starting from the beginning for every campaign mission and you're a fan of business sims and casual puzzle games, this could be a good fit.

24220524.review:
In [b][i]Big Pharma[/i][/b], you take the role of a CEO of a pharmaceutical company, and you have to take your fledgling company from minor painkiller pusher to mega-corporate cancer killer.

At the start of the game, you are dumped into an empty factory lot where you will be able to start building production machines and start manufacturing some cures. Each segment of the factory will have an input point where you can choose to pull through certain ingredients which may or may not have positive attributes. Running these ingredients through a careful setup of specific machines will either emphasise or dissipate the base positive or negative effects of your ingredients. Once you’re happy with the result, throw what you have into a pill machine and pipe it out through one of your output points where it will be given a name and shipped off into the world to be sold. 

You can also put scientists hard at work to research some brand new machines and ingredients, or simply improve existing ones. This is a nice way to improve the quality of your production lines and keep a consistent, stable way of producing reliable cures and boost profits the legitimate way.

The [b][i]Marketing and Malpractice[/i][/b] DLC helps to give you more control on the money side of things, and instead of just selling a cure for a set price throughout you can hike the cost of a drug when you know the demand is high and people are in desperate need of it; something as simple as a paracetamol may be in high demand after a tragedy somewhere in the world, and you can use it as an opportunity to charge a fortune for it. You can also undercut a competitor to gain your own company more money at the expense of theirs, adding new ways to play [b][i]Big Pharma[/i][/b] and causing you to be savvy off the production floor as well.

[b][i]Big Pharma[/i][/b] does feel unique, as it’s rare to get an economic/sim game that was built from the design level up to be a morality play on human greed.
People who enjoy business sims, and want to engage with something that requires planning without overzealous micromangement may find [b][i]Big Pharma[/i][/b] to be the cure.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Unique morality play in a sim game
- Addictive gameplay 
- Adds a new personal approach to playing
- Perks system

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Feels somewhat barren
- Suffers from repetitive gameplay
- Once you’ve played around with the features it loses appeal

[h1]7/10[/h1]

DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | [b][u]GOOD[/u][/b] | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

23851359.review:
Surprisingly good game. Put way more hours into this than I thought I ever would and I keep on playing. It keeps you engaged, when you work a problem out like compacting a production line into the smallest space possible in a cramped factory you legit feel good about it. Then your heart sinks when the market for that product falls out. Luckily you can save money, look for another ingredient that needs to be processed in a similar manner and with minimal effort crank out another drug. Or instead of selling the machinery at a loss you could re-use machinery different configurations or manufacturing lines to make a completely new process for another ingredient. Another thing, ingredients are randomized. This means you cannot make the same thing the same way. Ever. Each time you load a new level you have to think on the fly, formulate what conentrations you want, and if it's worth processing an ingredient enough to remove side effects. Sometimes side effects disappear with almost no effort, other times it's too cost prohibitive to even try unelss you want to make a drug at a profit-loss. 

What furthers the gameplay is competition. There are AI that can do exactly what you do in the game. All the dirty tricks and good recipes. They might not be as good as a human right out of the gate, you are typically the first to release a product, but each personality of AI can specialize in certain things. The CEO fellow goes around putting patents on easily made drugs like a prick, the nerdy looking old man makes very high-level drugs typically quicker than I would, sometimes an AI will make enough of a product that it drops market demand so you won't be on top in that market. This helps keep the game very fresh at all times, you don't know which AI you are facing and they can give you a run for your money at times. 

I can keep raving on for hours. I like this game a lot. It's not expensive, it's very cheap for what you get. It can run on Linux just fine, I play it on LinuxMint17 and the mouse isn't as responsive as windows but this isn't an FPS, you can pause this game any time you want. The expansion is an honest expansion and worth the $6 full price, adds so much more to Big Pharma. Very good game, it genuinely surprised me how much fun it is.

This is a delightful combination between a simulation game and a puzzle game.  The UI is elegant and flows well, especially with recent updates which puts more information at your fingertips.  This is one of my favorite sim games, with market considerations, timing releases, and strategizing about when and if to patent a drug.  On the flip side, you have to puzzle out your factory layout to ensure you use space efficiently while also keeping costs as low as possible.  It will often present interesting pro/cons considerations when building a layout between space efficient vs cost efficient machines.

Definitely get this if you don't mind mixing your building/sim games with your puzzle games.  Also - don't expect a pure sandbox mode.  Befitting a puzzle game environment, you play a series of scenarios with defined endpoints.  This is good, as unlike something like Prison Architect, this is a lot about building to that endpoint efficiently as opposed to building a factory and then maintaining it going forward.

I love it, you should get it!

23469639.review:
I love puzzle games, but I'm not afraid to admit when they get to be too much for me. SpaceChem is a perennial favorite of mine that I burned out on way before the end, for example. Big Pharma shares certain similarities with SpaceChem, but with a layer of corporate management on top of the mind-bending puzzles. It's an interesting combination, and also a very exhausting one.

You get to be the CEO of a pharmaceutical company, which turns out to be a lot more interior design and number-crunching than the vlogging and buying Wu-Tang albums that I expected. Starting with a small empty room, you import ingredients through hatches in the walls, run them through a gauntlet of machines, and funnel the resulting pills, creams, and tinctures back out for a profit. Each ingredient has positive and negative effects that are activated at different concentrations, so your machines can raise, lower, and rescramble concentrations to make effective medicines.

Cramming all the necessary machines and connecting conveyor belts into the space you have is your primary concern. You can research and unlock more efficient machines but you're trading space efficiency for higher running costs, which must be weighed against the profit of the drug. These values in turn fluctuate with the cost of ingredients, the market demand for that cure, and any competitor companies in that market. This is the management layer I spoke of and while you can do well enough ignoring price fluctuations, more difficult scenarios and the Master-level goals require you to retool your operation based on the market, especially once patents come into play and companies start locking each other out of producing specific cures.

This additional layer of complexity may be unwelcome to those just trying to wrap their brains about their assembly lines. Cures can be upgraded to more valuable remedies by hitting specific concentrations with specific machines. This sometimes requires catalysts mixed in with special machines, which might also require re-arranging your chemical's traits with yet another machine. All of these processes must then be crammed into limited space, and layout mistakes can be costly to undo. An efficient, profitable line is incredibly gratifying to put together, but it can be a difficult road to get there.

You'll have over three dozen scenarios to choose from, with goals ranging from make X dollars over Y years to deliver Z quantity of a specific drug. Regardless of your goals, the means will be similar, building assembly lines for simple drugs while you research the ingredients and tools to make more complex ones, and refactoring everything when you start to run out of space. New machines, upgrades, and rules may come into play in later scenarios, but never to particularly dramatic effect. It's one of those games where you really have to love the core gameplay loop because it's not going to deviate much from scenario to scenario.

The presentation is perfect for a puzzle game, with clear, colorful, cartoony shapes and pleasing animations for all your machines. I want to give special recognition to the sound effects, which reach Blizzard-levels of polish for how perfect and gratifying they are to hear. Machines make delightful buzzes and clanks, belts whirr along happily, and even the buttons have rich bleeps and bloops to them. It's an excellent concept assembled and presented as well as anyone could expect, so the only question is how long you'll care to stick with it. There's not a lot of variety to building lines or running your company, but if you want to build Rube Goldbergian conveyors and tax your brain in turning a profit, you'll find no end of content to keep you happy.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

23025904.review:
It's one of those games that you start over and over and over and over trying to make it better next time. Only to realize that, well, you won't. The theme of the game is, basically, building a pipeline from a start to a finish point with some machines in between to "produce" your pharaceuticals. The tricky part is that every type of machine has a defined input point and a defined output point, which means that if you have to put like 5 of them behind each other, you will invariably end up either in a circle or in a really bad design.

Solving this is, basically, the game.

Is it still fun? Surprisingly, yes it is. The graphics is cute enough to make it fun to watch that machine do its magic, and the liberty you have to make decisions is just enough to give you something to ponder. Should you scrap that low profit production line and hope that you can squeeze in the much larger one that gets you better profit? Do you have room to use three cheaper machines than one expensive one? Should you hire more scientists to make production cheaper in the long run, even though they're expensive to hire and maintain? 

Is it good enough to warrant the price tag? I'd say yes, but I wouldn't pay more than that.

22870728.review:
Overview
I have played for over 30 hours without mods or cheats and do not own the expansion pack. So far I have managed to progress to Intermediate level in the scenarios. From my experience this game is what a sim management should be.  With a bit of twisted humour thrown into the mix seen in classics such as Theme Hospital, Big Pharma is beautifully made and very entertaining with a lot of replayability. 

Interface and graphics
The main menu looks like a mobile port but don't be fooled! The simplistic buttons and side menus in the main game add to the overall functionality of the game. There are options to change the resolution, sound and graphic quality in the game. The graphics are in the cartoon style. I personally prefer this because cartoon style graphics will age much slower than the more realistically styled games, if at all.

Gameplay
There are 3 game modes for you to play - Free Play, Custom Game and Scenario. Free Play is the sandbox level where every machine and research branch is already unlocked and you have no money. Custom Game is where you set your own criteria to win the game. All of the goals/criteria in the game are number based and it would be nice to have a little more variety in how you win like being the most or least ethical competitor in game (but this might be in the expansion). Other than that the gameplay is solid. There is a lot of scope for replayability. There are 3 ranks in each game: standard, expert and master. The higher up the rank, either you have to do more within the standard time limit, or you have a shorter amount of time to complete your criteria. It's not just about what the game tells you to do as I find that I set myself personal goals long after I have finished my game criteria on a certain level. 

A few funny bugs
I have experienced some world events that were not logical at certain times. An example of this is the 'mild winter' event that popped up in May. I was also stuck on the 'Keep calm and carry on' scenario for a bit because none of the raw ingredients that were available to be explored in the game had the certain enzyme that I needed to be able to upgrade my drug to an anti-anxiety treatment. I made sure to explore all of the available areas.

My verdict
This is a great game. It gets really addictive so don't pick this game up if you want to be productive. A solid 10.

When I tried to make it more helpful to the populace in general, it ended up being not as profitable and I had to chuckle about the irony of that compared to real life (something I think the game designers intended to represent.) 22847054.review:
Buggy game.

Imagine you have a really efficient system, and a nice long machine, connecting each part to another in perfect harmony. You then add a machine that slows down the process slightly, and although you're limited by space, you see a small opportunity to add in another machine to help increase profits.

You spend the last of your money getting everything in place, then connect it all with belts. Suddenly, everything but your new addition grinds to a halt, as it turns out one of the belts in the new T-junction you've created is trying to move in the opposite direction.

You scratch your head, thinking "but there's an input and an output... why can't it see which way to go? Everntually, you contact the developer, who says "It's literally impossible to fix this"... You then realise that the developer simply doesn't know how to fix this bug, and therefore calls it a feature, telling people not to use T-Junctions, even though they limit the space provided, and encourage you to connect machines together and utlise space as best as possible.

It's a nice game, and certainly a time sink, but whomever designed the belts system needs to go back and do them again. Especially as they're the most used object in the game.

It's not going to happen though... as the developer refuses to admit there's a problem, despite the number of people arguing their point.

For that reason alone, it's not recommended. You'll find yourselves more frustrated than entertained.

22808856.review: Innovative, well thought out and challenging

22804811.review: Big Pharma is a wonderful game. Where else can you create a drug to combat erectile dysfunction, with the possible side effects of anal leakage, then name it "Erecto Blaster 9000"??

22784806.review:
As a fan of games like Spacechem, the old Mysts and 7th Guest, TIS-100 even and pretty much any other that requires heavy thinking, I really don't get why there are "so many" (22% as of now) bad reviews about this game.

Big Pharma is not as hard on your brain as some of these games I mentioned above but it does require a fair amount of thought and planning, specially at the begining when you're not used to it, and the hardest levels are also pretty challenging.

Put simply (if you're not in the mood for reading everything): the game is good, it keeps you entertained and focused for plenty of time.

People writing bad reviews mostly claim that:

1 - The game gets repetitive/boring - I disagree. Well, ok, every game gets repetitive - even life itself does - and Big Pharma is no exception. Still, you always get a rewarding sense of accomplishment when you see your production lines running efficiently, your drugs selling more than your competitors (and for a higher price) and when you get good trial reviews because you're a good man and ran the extra mile to make them patient-friendly. Also, every level has a different objective, and you can get a standard, expert or master "score" on each, depending on how fast (usually) you achieved your objective, and that keeps you on your toe every time, avoiding any mistakes to get your "master" rank in every level. You do, indeed, start every single level with the same formula (slight variations, but the same routine), but I find the game is still fun after 20+ hours playing it, mainly because achieving the master rank in the toughest levels is a good challenge.

2 - The "managing aspect" isn't a big part of the game - Again, I disagree. You absolutely need the money aspect, and it fits the game perfectly in my opinion. You must keep your drugs (and their sales rating, if you have the DLC, which I recommend) profitable, your income on the green, to be able to keep going. You must beat your competitors (and fast) or they'll end up showering you with patents and taking a huge share of the market, diminishing your sales. You gotta be careful with the loans you get so their interest don't end up eating all of of your profits, and also balance how many explorers/scientists you have - and what they are currently working on - to keep enough cash flowing in and your company, again, ahead of the competition. In my opinion, the management aspect works perfectly with the puzzle/logistic facet of Big Pharma. It's a double-fun experience, specially if you're the type of person who enjoys both things.

I think that covers most of the "thumbs down" this game has received.

***

About the DLC:

If you liked the base game, you'll like the DLC. It adds some neat new features (check the DLC's steam page for specifics.)

***

On a serious note / Something special about this game:

There's a very interesting and particular side to Big Pharma: it opens your eyes for how the REAL "Big Pharma Industry" works, or at the very least it makes you think about it.

In this game, you can leave side-effects on drugs on purpose (and regulate their, as well as the cure's, strenght as you will) to keep demand for some of your other drugs (those that treat such side effects) up high. You can patent your drugs to get a temporary monopoly of a market's share and raise your prices up to the sky. With the DLC, you can run trials on your drugs and deliberately disqualify the bad results to trick the consumers and raise  your sales. You... see where I'm going with this.

After playing this game, one must wonder: "Dude... this can totally be done for real. Maybe real companies do this kind of stuff." Then you keep thinking about it and... "Why wouldn't they? Well... maybe they have principles, and goodness in their heart. Maybe they want to help people." But wait... we're talking about some of the (if not THE) richest people in the world, people you never heard about, people whose names no one knows. People who torture lab animals on a daily basis, who tested prototype-drugs on jew prisoners during Hitler's Reich. People who profit from the suffering of the sick and weakened, and make a living extorting the dying. People who steal an old guy's economies dry under false promises of an unlikely cure (**Google "cancer" here**).

Finally, you'll find yourself concluding: "Man... screw politicians, mexican cartels, weapon dealers and african warlords. Big Pharma - that's the real nemesis of mankind."

I just read that Johnson & Johnson was just condemned to pay an indemnification of 55 million dolars to a woman because one of their talc powders gave her cancer. The doctors had to remove her ovary, and it was literally lined with talc. And that's a second (at least) for them because, months ago, they had to pay 72 million to another woman for the same reason.

If this example and reason alone aren't enough for you, Google "Big Pharma" or any company's specific name (Johnson & Jhonson, Pfizer, etc.) and read for yourself.

What I know is I'm never taking any medicine again unless it's strictly necessary (AKA I'm in heavy, constant pain). If you keep thinking about all this stuff, it's easy to see how far these companies can/could/do go to take your money (like an infinite chain of side-effects and their temporary-with-more-side-effects treatments). Seriously, we are on the "genetic mapping age", how hard can it be for trillionaires (the Big Pharma industry generates a trillion dolars per year) to cut off side effects and balance a drug's components if they want to? Damn, even I can do it, according to Big Pharma (the game).

***

Conclusion:

Big Pharma is a very nice game. It gives you a sense of reward every time you score a "master" on the tough levels and that's the raw thing every game aims for. If you like puzzle/management games, I'd say this one should keep the average guy entertained for 30-40 hours, maybe more (it took me 70 hours just to get "Master" on all the levels in "Advanced" and beyond). That's good value for your money, and this is the kind of game that you start playing at 6pm, play for one or two hours straight, quit, and realize it's already 11pm.

If you're concerned about the negative reviews (I always and seriously take them into account myself) maybe you can wait for a sale, but I really don't think you'll regret your purchase at full price, as long as you understand what the game is like (the screenshots alone can give you a fair idea) and feel you are going to enjoy it - the game's execution itself is great, that is not going to disappoint you.

EDIT: btw, I never got a single bug or crash whatsoever.

EDIT 2: ok, now the game has crashed once, after 45 hours or so.

EDIT 3: I just found out that this game was made by ONE dude, alone. That always baffles me (Terraria was also made by a single guy, if I'm not mistaken). I, myself, can barely get dressed on my own, so... congratulations, Tim, amazing job.

22778231.review:
Big Pharma is a management/strategy/puzzle game where you have to build and manage a medicine company. You can say it’s a business simulation puzzle tycoon. You build, research, develop new medicine all the while trying to maximize profits. There is one part of the game that focuses on the production aspect of the medicines, in this part you have to concentrate on researching new medicine/cures and try to improve your medicine overall. The second part of the game is the economics of your company. You basically have to earn profit and try to improve medicine.

[b][u] Graphics: [/u][/b]

The graphics are simple yet beautiful looking. The colors are very bright and eye-catching. It almost sort of has that cartoon look. There’s not many options in the graphics menu other than resolution adjustment. 

[b][u] Sound: [/u][/b]

The music in the game is okay, you won’t get bored from it but it’s nothing to write home about as well. The announcer voice can sometimes become annoying though. Other than that most of the sounds work as they should and not bad at all.

[b][u] Gameplay:  [/u][/b]

The majority of the game is based on missions, where you start out with $50000 and you have a task. For example the first mission has you earn a certain amount of revenue in 10 years. Most of the missions are like that and as you keep doing missions the next batch of missions gets harder and harder. There’s a lot of missions and even free mode where you can just play without having to worry about anything. There will be a rival company which also influences your company when they introduce new drugs etc. 

There’s also a puzzle element of fitting your medicine making machinery in a limited space, so figuring that out can be a lot of fun. You can choose from 8 different characters when you start a game. There are perks when you start a new game. E.G a perk where refunding equipment gives you 100% money back instead of regular 50%. You can choose 2 perks, at the beginning there’s only 4 perks unlocked but you can unlock more as you do missions and do the objectives the said perk requires. It’s a very strategic game where everything you do has an effect eventually so you must make your decisions well thought out. Game can be pretty complicated so if you like serious management games, this game is for you.

The DLC “Marketing and Malpractice” adds a whole bunch of add-ons to the game such as marketing tools where you can adjust your prices of your drugs as per the demand/demand, you basic economics. This basically changes they way the game works with your competitors as you can undercut their prices. You can give “gifts” and other such to doctors to increase sales. The DLC in my opinion makes the game much more interesting and gives it that new perspective of playing. 

[b][u] Graphics: 8/10 [/u][/b]
[b][u] Sound: 7/10 [/u][/b]
[b][u] Gameplay: 8/10 [/u][/b]
[b][u] Overall: 8/10 [/u][/b]

[b][u] Conclusion: [/u][/b]

Big Pharma is an excellent time waster and a very good business/tycoon/simulator/puzzle game. Though prepare to spend plenty of time learning the ins and outs of the game as it can get very complicated. All in all it’s a fun title and the DLC is pretty nice as well.

However, once you start making some serious money in a few years, you can just get caught up in designing the perfect drug for each disease and then creating the production layout for it in tight factory spaces. 

Some reviewers have mentioned that drug designing is a simple matter of increasing or decreasing the concentration but I think that those players have not yet discovered other aspects of drug designing which really compel you to look at all the possibilties and then create that Viagra-like drug that will change the world!

The best part, perhaps, is that all these complexities offer value to those players who wish to indulge in them. If you just want to keep it simple, you can easily make enough money by just producing simple generic drugs.

22593113.review:
Big Pharma is a very refreshing take on factory building that offers genuine satisfaction for coming up with the best production line you can think of.  Where similar games get by overloading with content and chaos--more things to build, higher volume, etc, Big Pharma rewards for elegant solutions.  It isn't about how much you produce.  It's about how you produce it.

For simplicity's sake, I will contrast Big Pharma with Factorio, which I also got a lot of enjoyment from.  Factorio is about managing resources and logistics--incredibly large numbers of exceedingly simple tasks that combine to create hectic situations.  The entire game (Factorio) can be summed up as deciding what you want to make, then ensuring the right buildings are getting the right amounts of all requisite materials in a massive and complicated chain involving dozens of buildings.  All gameplay revolves around that.

Big Pharma is absolutely nothing like that; rather, it is about design and decision making.  Where Factorio gets complicated, Big Pharma is merely complex.  In Big Pharma, you can make whatever sort of cure you like.  Expensive or cheap, whether you earn or lose money is determined by *how* you chose to make the product and whether it was a wise choice to make it at all considering demand, competition, and your current capabilities.  You can make crazy wonder drugs and lose money with a hasty production line a la Factorio, or you can put some thought into it and make millions.  The same applies to the cheap drugs.  Maybe you even allow a minor, negative side effect in the product to ensure economic viability.  It's up to you to determine what the right move is, and when you make that right move, you get genuine satisfaction out of it that games like Factorio are simply incapable of matching.

I am not saying that Big Pharma is better than Factorio.  I got a lot more time out of Factorio than I did from Big Pharma.  But I do believe the time I spent with Big Pharma was more enjoyable and satisfying, which is quite fitting.  Production in Factorio is all about volume, and production in Big Pharma is all about quality and substance.  This mirrors my gameplay experience with the two games quite nicely.

22407646.review:
Big Pharma requires you to fit a number of tetris-shaped machines in as little space as possible in order to make drugs for profit. I'd love to say there was more to the game than that, but sadly there really isn't. All the challenges are basically the same, which makes the game very repetitive and it gets boring very, very fast. SImply not worth the price. You can get mobile games for free that are much more worthwhile and will give you many more hours of entertainment.

I bought this in early access (and got the Steam version for free, but never played it on Steam) and expected a lot more to be added to the game, but was then surprised when the release date was announced, constantly thinking "that has to be a mistake, it's not remotely done." But no, Tim considered it done and it was released. Sorry, Tim, but you made a bad game.

The good part:
- Figuring out how to turn ingredients into drugs using as few machines as possible is fun, at first. 
- Trying to create crazy drugs by combining different cures that aren't normally combined can be fun, at first.
- Watching all the machines work is fun, for a while.
- You can name all your drugs whatever you want, which is also compeltely pointless because there's no multiplayer so there's no one to laugh at the names you use.

But then comes all the bad (and the list is only short because there's so little to the game):

You have AI opponents who for the most part only seem to be there as decoration. They're no real challenge and even with the patents it's not a problem to beat them because you can just make another drug that's slightly different. You never feel cornered or like you have to rush. The only challenge remains beating the timer if you care at all about scoring gold on everything (which in itself doesn't earn you anything whatsoever other than a golden line on the scenario selection screen).

Once you beat the first scenario you know how to beat the rest of the game. The only thing that changes is how fast you have to make your money and what drugs you can make. Nothing else changes.

Tim (the developer) has a background in simple mobile games and it shows in Big Pharma: It lacks depth, it lacks complexity, and everything is over-simplified to the point where you have no control over any of the things that would have made the game remotely interesting. I wasn't the only one who asked for a more complex economy, but Tim felt it wasn't needed. Unfortuntely having no control over the economy means it doesn't really matter what you do because prices fluctuate at random. It also means that half the info screens don't matter because you can't do much at all to affect your economy anyway.

Tim's idea that "scoring gold on a mission can be incredibly motivating" doesn't fly when the game is so incredibly boring to play and has no real content. You simply have nothing to do, ever, other than plopping down the machines, connecting them with belts, and trying not to lose count of whether you needed two or three machines to get the right concentration.

Meanwhile you scream for more to do and bang your head against the wall to express your frustration for yet another incomplete game that was released with no plans for more content.

22228040.review:
A tycoon/simulator game where you build production lines for medicine. There is no story mode/campaign but rather many scenarios that require you to reach a certain objective (like a target revenue) within a time limit.

You start with an open area and have to build production lines for medicine. You start with a vent on the wall to import raw ingredients, pass it through several processing machines to refine and produce the medicine, then end with a vent on the wall to export the completed product. There are a variety of machines and you'll have to make decisions on how to make your medicine. There are tradeoffs in space, manufacturing speed, profit, and quality of medicine based on which and how many machines you use. Also, there is a research system in place that requires you to invest money to eventually unlock more ingredients, machines, and other bonuses,

Certain things could be better polished/presented:
[list]
[*]The tutorial could be better- it's just one long scrollable text box. I would've liked a tutorial that was properly divided into separate windows for each step and with UI focus (like highlighting/pointer arrows, etc.) on what is being talked about. It's not too hard to learn if you've played similar games or have a knack with understanding program UI but the tutorial could use some polishing up.
[*]At first glance it seemed that there were only 4 columns of challenges but one day I was surprised when my mouse cursor wandered to the right edge of the screen and it scrolled a little. There's no reason to move your mouse all the way to the right (you can hover over the right-most challenges without scrolling the screen)
[*]Sometimes it's hard to click on a specific thing (like vents to change ingredients or to delete specific tiles of that are partially hidden behind things). It's due to perspective but there has to be some way to better select objects in the back. You have to click on a certain area for vents that you'll have to learn by experience.
[/list]

There are a couple UI changes I would have liked:
[list]
[*]To have a dedicated area to see current active events. I couldn't find the details anywhere after I dismissed the event box. After a while you can manually check the graphs for the changes but it would still be a nice addition.
[*]To toggle ingredient icons while zoomed out (normally, all icons disappear). I liked to use the icons to figure out which areas are making which product (which is useful when you want to change production).
[*]To find the location of your product line by clicking on the product in your company tab
[*]To display the amount of ingredient currently being used in the upgrade tooltip (like the machine upgrade tooltip). This would let you know at a glance which ingredient you're using a lot (so how much the upgrade would benefit you).
[*]'Auto pause and focus' is nice but it will sometimes not work if you've currently opened another event window. Your product line (and its revenue) will stop completely while it waits for you to name a product so the product naming window should really always pause and force you to deal with it (Or the product should keep selling under the generic name until you name it).
[/list]

Personally, I would've liked a campaign or scenarios with personalities and scripted events to make things interesting. A little story to link things together helps keep my interest when doing multiple playthroughs of the same thing. The sandbox is fun for a while but it's not like The Sims where it's easy to make your own story in the sandbox. I had fun doing a few challenges and then went straight to a custom game with all tier levels unlocked to get the full experience.

Worth a look if you like sandbox tycoon games and refining your strategy through multiple playthroughs.

21439688.review:
Big Pharma is a great little game in which you get to play as the big pharmaceutical companies, create drugs, sell them and build up reputation.

The game is in essens a puzzle game with some light management thrown in for good measure. Most of the gameplay is creating drug chains that optimizes drugs (for profit or usefulness) and then to sell them. Which is really a really satisfying puzzle game. All of the machines that create drugs have a different shape and size and in order to fit them all in you either need to plan out what you'll need ahead of time, because moving production lines after they are completed is really difficult, alternatively you can buy smaller more effective machines, however those will crank up the production cost for the drug, directly affecting your bottom line.

The game is great in that you can create really weird drugs that may or may not actually work, but after all it's all about making money and not drugs right? You will need to decide wheater you value space efficiency vs price, what research should you prioretize. All the while trying to stay ahead of the competition which have just patented your new drug formula rendering the giganormous production line you just created, worthless...

It's a great little zen game where once in a while you sit back and just wait for your drugs' ratings go up or down, accumulate money etc. Contemplating weather or not it's the right time to expand, what you should expand into, is it worth optimizing that one cure so that its drug rating goes up...

There's almost always something to do, at least in the beginning and then the game zens out after a while.

One bad thing about the game however is that when you get to a sort of "critical mass" you basically cannot lose, except  for deadlines. There's not really too many challenges after the initial ones, because when you manage to get enough drugs to sell, you will start making tons of money and the game really turns into a fine tuning game. I'm not saying it isn't  fun at that point, but it really doesn't require as much baby sitting.

On the other hand that might be exactly what you're looking for as you can then sit and maybe catch up on a series, Youtube etc.

All in all, it's a nice little game, especially if you can get it in a sale, great if you need something to stimulate that gamer part of the brain as you catch up on videos or whatever. I for one can't just sit and do one thing at a time, so this is a great game for me. :)

21336233.review:
I played this game quite a bit in pre-Steam alpha - I recommend this game only to those who enjoy puzzle games, I'd say it's worth it if you can get it on sale for 10 bucks or less. 

If you are looking for a tycoon/management game, this is not it.


------

I was originally intrigued because it reminded me a bit of Theme Hospital, which - like most Bullfrog games, I loved - but this doesn't play like a tycoon game, or a management game. It's more of a puzzle game. 

Think Tetris where you have to research the different pieces. 

This game cries out for a sandbox mode... where you can build a room, build an import, layout your machinery, then build an export - use the funds to research/innovate/explore etc - enlarge your factory, add more production lines, make more money, stay ahead of the competition. 

Instead you get numerous scenarios in which you have to gain an arbitrary amount of money and/or create a specific type of medicine by a certain date and/or before the competiton. 

The game itself is that you fit your production line into a predetermined amount of space. The ingredients must be researched and require various amounts of machines (which must also be researched) to get them into medically effective states. Your work out the logistics to make it all fit. Rinse, repeat. 

Personally, I dislike scenario games like this; any game where I'm asked to spend time building something only to leave it all behind and start again from scratch level after level, wears thin on me rather quickly.

That said, the game is extremely well made in terms of quality, the UI has been streamlined and overall it's very solid. This dev knows what they're doing, and I look forward to more of their work.

21303097.review:

However, it also ties into the management size - can you make the drugs without them turning a loss instead of a profit? And do you let side-effects in to save money?

* Management: Balancing the books, making profit from the drugs, and balancing research and exploration for new ingredients.

The developer also seems to be continuing to support the game, having released an update recently to make the UI alittle better, and balance the game more.

In short, I don't think it'll be everyone's cup of tea, but for me, its been grand and fun.

21084591.review:
See what it feels like to be Martin Shkreli, in this pharmaceutical company management sim, ... well maybe not. In Big Pharma you do manage a pharmaceutical company but it's more of a puzzle game with management elements. 

Big part of the gameplay is placing various machines that increase or decrease concentration of ingredients or mix them up and finally turn them into pills or creams or syringes. All these machines have different input and output locations and often sizes, you also need to add conveyor belts and with limited amount of space and doors through which ingredients can enter and leave your factory creating a new drug becomes, well a puzzle. Besides planning your factory you'll send explorers in search of new ingredients and researchers to invent new types of machines or improve existing ones. 

You can play in free mode or one of many challenges. What is really smart and should be adopted in other games is that the challenges get progressively more complex. And I don't mean that the competition gets tougher or you are hit with arbitrary debuffs. The game actually limits your research tree and ingredient list to only present you with simple choices. Then as you progress you are given more and more options. It's a really nice game that hits that improvement itch, you've created a cure for bad breath and now you can improve it and cure sore throat. Coming up with more and more complex recipes for more advanced cures is extremely satisfying. 

[b]Dad rating: Excellent[/b]
[list]
[*]Game can be paused at any time, giving you time to attend to the little ones. Speed can also be increased if you prefer to breeze through the more boring periods.
[*]No violence what so ever. No scary monsters jumping out on the screen either. You can safely play it with your child on your knees.
[/list]

I highly recommend it my 10h with Big Pharma felt like a breeze and I'm looking forward to many more.

20887885.review:
I don't like puzzle games. That's my story and I'm sticking to it. I bought this game because it's a business management simulator. Thing is, the business management part is only half of it, if that. The restf is very much a puzzle game, but not one that requires you to go so in depth with your puzzle solving thinking that you end up with a migraine.

When playing Big Pharma, you'll notice that most of your time is spent, with the game paused, trying to fit equipment into spaces that make it work well with other equipment, within the constraints of the sometimes awkwardly shaped space provided. Sometimes you'll find yourself thinking "Geez, they must have made this chain of machines incompatible with this dumb building on purpose", while at other times you'll think "Wow, this fits so perfectly here, without wasting any space at all, that I must be doing something right!" Odds are pretty good that the reality is somewhere in the middle, where there wasn't much thought put into it at all aside from using the shapes of the buildings to throttle the difficulty. You will be annoyed at the lack of space, irritated with the AI for seeming to be able to patent something just as you're ramping up to produce it, but overall, you will get a sense of strange euphoria, seeing your machinations chug along, making you lots of money -- and it is pretty darn easy to make lots of money in this game. That part isn't hard. The difficulty definitely comes from making the pieces fit in a way that accomplishes your goals, effeciently and on timie, without blocking you from making the next line. 

This is a great game to play with the background music turned off and your favorite tunes playing instead. That's not to say that the background music is bad. It's just mediocre, and mostly pointless. 

The graphics look exactly like they should for a game such as this -- good enough. They're not realistic but they're not so cartoony as to be a distraction from the puzzle aspects.

There is no story or campaign or anything. The closest you get is the "challenges" screen, which is the first thing you see when you click "New Game", and offers various scenarios with challenges attached. There is a tutorial which is both easy to use and fairly comprehensive, though you'll probably have to Google some of the higher tier equipment to see how they work. The information is not hard to find, though, so that's not really a downside. 

Overall, Big Pharma is a pretty good game. The simplicity will draw you in and keep you hooked even well past the point where you're tired of doing the same things over and over again and, really, that's its biggest rub -- redundancy. From the moment you play the first game in the "Beginner" column to the moment you put it away, you're doing pretty much the same thing over and over again. Think about it as an assembly line simulation tied in with some simplified business management concepts and you've got a good idea of what Big Pharma is all about.

You're simply placing machines in a way that will be as efficient as you can make them. Everything else is just details. Is that a bad thing? In this case, I don't think it is. To me, the repitition gave me a sense of comfort, knowing that, at the beginning of every scenario, I had at least some *idea* of what I was doing. The first level drugs are extremely easy to make, and they get you off the ground pretty quickly, though you are forced to get more complicated since you'll oversaturate the market with them if you just make those. It was when the idea of starting fresh became significantly more appealing than continuing to try and get Master Level of accomplishment at a scenario that I realized it was probably time to play something else. However, that was 80 hours in, which is not a bad return for a game that costs $25 when it's not on sale! I'll probably go back to it at some point, too.

I wish there was a way to write a neutral, as I could go either way on this game.

Obviously, I have played a lot of hours, but as another reviewer mentioned, you get to the point of wanting to complete all the missions/scenarios instead of playing for fun.

Figuring out how the machines work, strategies for making money, etc are fun at first.  What happens is it takes some time to get machines unlocked, etc. while playing in missions, so you find yourself doing essentially the same strategy for every scenario up to the point of fulfilling the mission objectives.  For example, several missions are "earn xxx profit in xxx time" - well that's easy enough once you have done it for $1,000,000 you can do it for $10,000,000.  There are missions like "cure xxx xxx times" or "supply xxx drugs", again, once you do those once, it's fairly easy to repeat.  The AI players are pretty much a non-threat.

I believe there's a good 20 hours of playtime in the game.  After that, it starts to become repetitive.

My advise:  Buy it on sale.  $15 or under would be OK.

To the devs:  Game is good but too expensive for what it is - I wish the missions were more varied.  I wish you could really ramp up the difficulty and the AI was an actual competitior.  For example, being able to bankrupt the AI or having the AI complete the same mission objectives you are would be good.
