20292320.review:
This game is a unique blend of big-picture simulation and puzzle like supply chain management that I think anyone who likes sim or puzzle games should look into. I definitely recommend it on sale to a fan of either genre.  Otherwise, it is more of a niche game than I thought it would be, which makes it tough for me to recommend to the average gamer.  I followed this game since the first dev vlogs came out, then bought it in the beta phase, and for me there was just enough that the game did well that made it worth me supporting it before release.

[b]Pros[/b]:
+ Supply Chain Management Tycoon: This is something unique that it does very well regarding drug creation/production. If you're not into Sim and Puzzle type games, then think twice before buying the game.
+ Scenario Variety and Customization: Dozens of scenarios of varying difficulties with the ability to create your own.
+ AI / Competition: I didn't find competing companies to be unrealistically hard or easy. With 3+ competitors, innovation to different drug types are imperative.
+ Macro management (other than supply chain): Dev explicitly stated that the game wasn't designed for micro managing a pharmacy company. Big picture management is done well though with plenty of Research & Development opportunities, and it doesn't bog you down with price management or small stuff.
+ Subtle ethical decisions: Some people wanted to be hit over the head with this, but again, it seemed secondary in the eyes of the dev. The decisions currently come in the form of...Do I leave this side effect or weak cure as is because my profit will be higher? Do I stop production on a drug that is still in demand just to move on to higher level cures with larger profits? Do I "research" corporate espionage in order to see my competitors' profit margins, etc?

[b]Cons[/b]:
-Incentiveize the game play loop: There's 3 completion levels for each scenario indicating how well the player did, but that, scenario uniqueness, or making a specific type of drug (e.g. hair growing male enhancement drug) seems about it for replay motivation.
-Starting drug RNG (may be fixed): I've read about a number of players restarting scenarios until their initial unlocked drug combo was ideal. This may be more of a player min/maxing issue, and I think a patch meant to address this, but I don't know how well this helped.
-Micro management (by design): As mentioned above, the game wasn't designed for that, and this may bug some people. Just supply chain and big picture stuff is what is mostly in this game.

20272632.review:
A neat "puzzle" and problem-solving game.   Sure, you could cure a big disease and get paid handsomely for it too... the problem is that you'll cure your customer base.  Wouldn't it be better to have return customers by alleviating their condition without curing it?  You'll make a bit less per pill, but since it won't cure them, they'll have to purchase it every month.

Now that you've seen the light, how do you produce this pill with your current factory?  Oh, that machine costs too much to run - let's make a slightly weaker version of the pill by using a different machine. Sure, the pill isn't as effective as before, but you make $20 more ...

See how this goes? 

I'd recommend this game for anyone who enjoys a good business sim.  The financial decisions are tougher than the "puzzle" decisions, so though I'd still recommend the game for problem-solver types, I think they'd have to enjoy business games too, whereas business game fans don't necessarily need to enjoy puzzles.

Tons of play time for only $25.00. Outstanding value for money if you're into this type of game. The time and effort spent on details, gameplay, and features really shows. This game is beautiful and it runs like butter on my very old 32-bit XP box (3GHz Athlon 64 X2 CPU, 4GB of DDR2 RAM), Radeon 6700-series video).

[Edit] Revision to the above. The game has crashed 4 times, once with an actual "The game has crashed"  dialog (creating a crash dump folder which I emailed to the developer), and 3 times it just locked up solid at various points., forcing me to Ctrl+Shift+Esc into Task Manager to kill the process. In fairness, It's possible that the problem may lie with my aging hardware.

Things I like:
1. Great combination of puzzle/strategy/simulation. Min/maxers will *love* this game!
2. Except for entering your company name and custom names for your saves (both of which are optional), game can be played entirely with the mouse.
3. So nice to have a "sandbox" mode to just goof around in as well as create your own levels/puzzles.
4. Also nice to be able to build/remove/adjust while paused.

One nit: As with many such real-time simulation games, there can be lengthy periods of "sit back, watch, and wait" but the visuals of your factory alleviate that somewhat.

19519922.review:
Played about 60 hours worth of the game so far, and have enjoyed it.  I have compeleted most of the missions offered in the game and have dabbled in the free-play/custom game mode.

Big Pharma is essentially a one part puzzle - one part economic/business simulator, as most of my fellow recommenders have already mentioned.  

As it is a two part game, both aspects of it become important at different times. 

Early game, the business aspect I feel is the more forefront of the two. Money is tight, and the AI at times can be brutal competitors either flooding the market for a product or squeezing you out of one. Not to say the game is too difficult, but for those who love business simulations, the early game is your niche.  Late game however, the game gives way to its puzzle aspect as the more pressing of the two. You both lose opportunities to flex your capital might as well as simply run out of space to place your production lines, usually resulting in having to forgo certain markets alltogether just to produce a high tier product. And one that is impossible to optimize at that. Some of the late game markets are quirky too  I feel - The Male Contraception treatments are apparently permanent (in any form, but pill form specifically just boggles my mind). 

For those who love business simulations though, I'd recommend giving the game a go.  Its drawbacks to me are more quirky than actual problems with the game itself and you can get decent value from the game at its listed price. 

In addition, I tink Mark Allsworth did a decent job with the games soundtrack.

19474563.review: This game brought me back to a time when buisiness sims ruled the PC. I havent played a great PC business sim in a long while, but this one falls into the category.

19413832.review:
This game has a very interesting concept, balancing both business simulation and logistics planning, making this one of the deepest and most challenging tycoon game yet. The random generation also allows for more challenging scenarios and replayability, but is also one of the downsides to the game, considering business simulation and RNG tend to dislike each other. I'm not far through the game yet, but it is starting to get repetitive, as most missions can be completed by the same general business strategy of "upgrade and expand as much as possible". Controls, UI, and other gameplay elements are handled well, so there's not much to say about that. 

[h1]Rating:[/h1]
[b]7/10[/b] Not a bad game at all, but I suggest getting it for a lower price due to the repetitive nature of its gameplay.

19405951.review:
It's easy to see that the developers have tried hard to make a good game based on a new idea. And they have gone 95% of the way, but the games still feels like a beta version of the real game. The controls are clumsy: you move around with the same right button as you sell; switching between tabs takes so much time, although you do it all the time; I still try to push escape to get to the main view (because it's natural!), but only get to the menu; the default building hotekys are on the numeric keyboard (do you think everyone has it?) and I still haven't found a hotkey for belts.

At the same time, the gameprocess is overloaded by messages and different areas in which your attention is required, which doesn't let you focus on something in particular, but always distracts you. The analysis of market is not well presented, so it's hard to understand what is the best course of action at the moment. Finally, fitting your equipment in the factory is interesting the first two minutes, but then you are kind of tired playing tetris and are more interested in concentrating on more important stuff, but nope, you cannot. And if you want to double your production you cannot copy a segment of your conveyor, but have to rebuild it againg with all the connections, which feels like a complete loss of time.

This game is a good try and may become something good in the end, but for the moment it is largely overpriced (I wouldn't pay more than 5$ for it) and in my opinion needs large sales and an army of beta-testers to make it playable for more than two hours. So be aware: for the moment this game is not what you expect. But it still has a change to become a good one.

19392451.review:
[I] This key was obtained from the developer for review purposes.[/i]

[u] Summary: [/u]
A surprisingly deep experience in the strategy genre. The game hits you over the head with the options for the custom game. Granted, it'll take a bit of time to understand all the elements the game, and the tutorial could be better at teaching you the game's elements. But once you get an understanding of everything the game has to offer, you'll find surprising depth. The game's strategy design is where it shines: what elements are adjustable and ones that are not are done with purpose and reason in my opinion. Dealing with competitors that actually can affect your gameplay in slight and even more direct ways was fun, and it made me a bit sad that there's no MP element of the game, as I really felt like the game could have truly shined there. When it comes down to it: I felt this game did something that I feel a lot of developers could learn from: start with a great base design, add the options later on, and designed it from the player's angle: and what they'd want. Rather impressed in the long run, and can recommend to strategy gamers out there.


[b] Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poYuUF9spzM [/b]

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]+:[/b]
[list]
[*] Lots of customization options in terms of gameplay, and in particular with the custom game. Really can change the elements down to the most specific growth rates and research trees that are available. A lot of strategy games can learn from this level of customization.
[*] I cover strategy games rarely because of the type of player that I am (I'm the builder type, basically consider me the opposite of the zerg play style), but this game was right up my alley in terms of my game style, but other game styles as well. 
[*] Good balance of gameplay elements that don't overly punish you for not using them, but reward you for taking advantage of them. Cost vs effectiveness of the drug does make a difference, especially in the early going, but both strategies can be viable.
[*] Found that it stood the test of time in terms of variety with the smaller elements. Despite me restarting a lot due to my own personal weaknesses (aka wanting to perfect situations and so repeatedly starting again), I still found myself having fun. 
[*] This may seem weird to say, but some of the elements that you'd expect that aren't there (like setting the price of the drug)
[*] Actually like the restricted playing fields. Causes you to have your own puzzle mini-game regarding machine placement that works rather well. 
[*] Did I mention there's a good selection of options? There's a good selection of options. 
[*] There's apparently mod support. That's always a plus. 
[/list]

[b]-:[/b]
[list]
[*] Takes a bit of time to get going in terms of understanding. Lots of information to digest, and it could have been passed on to the player easier in the end. Tutorial could have been done better.
[*] Little rough around some of the edges. In particular with things like the belt controls feel like that there may have been a better implementation. Luckily, it's something that you can easily get adjusted to in time. 
[*] Would have loved to see a MP version of the game, but understand the development costs that would be required in order for that to happen.
[/list]

19239878.review:
First off: I own this game from their website before the steam release, so my playtime is higher than the 0.4 hours it claims right now.

TLDR: Even though I like many aspects of the game, I can not recommend it at its price as it will not keep you entertained for very long.

Do I somewhat like the game? Yes.
Would I recommend it? Not really, especially not for 23 Euros.

I love the setting, I feel there should be way more disease/medical-related games and I do enjoy the graphics, by which I mean I don't mind the simplicity. I like the making of new drugs, the setting up of belts/arrangements, the tight budget, the slight humour, the ideas like exploration and the reasearch tree.

So why wouldn't I recommend it? Because it gets boring, and it does so rather quick. The reason for this is, that its repetetive. Gamesessions usually are done in 1-3 Hours depending on difficulty and consist of you researching new techs and producing new medications with increased difficulty in the setup of your conveyer-belts.

The Problem is that its the same each mission. And the Drugs/Ingredients are completly interchangeable. Unless youre a "Letsplayer" you wont care for the name of the made-up Drugs/Ingredients within seconds but they will just be stats like "increase/decrease concentration by 3" so thats all you do.

You find the easiest way to reach that wanted concentration. And theres only (when fully researched) like 3 ways of increasing decreasing, meaning +/- 1 ; +/-3 ; half/double. So thats not hard! In fact nothing is really "hard" in this game. Theres no need to make difficult choices, as you will most likely produce every medice you can as far as research and exploration go, since every "tick" gives money, theres also no need to think about if you should keep the medicine going - if it ticks in money, keep it, if it loses money, replace it.

The result is a very easy game and the "challange" comes from increasingly hard scenarios. But this doesn't mean anything interesting like "do this-and-that with 3 rooms" or so, no, while there are ~5 different types on missions they all play the same, as you just need to make more of the best kind of medicine, cure a number of people, make some money or something along those lines, so they all mean you build up your, lets say "empire" and then at some point you win. And weather your task is to make 5-super-medicines or to make X Million $ doesnt matter as you do the very same thing. The Difficulty of the Game (which does go quite high in the late game) only comes from increasingly narrow timelimits, so the medium and hard difficulty is identical, except in one you need to make (lets say, not sure about the real number right now as it doesnt matter) 5 Milion in 10 years and on hard its 10 Million in 5 Years.

So after 10 hours lets say you will start more than your 10th game (the easy games go by rather fast) and you will do the very same thing the 10th time in a row, still not caring. And since setting up the conveyer belt-systems is the only real aspect, and you do that about once every 5 minutes, you will have done that about 120 times. And then its just routine, theres no fun to be had (there hasn't been in quite a while) and all you do is click your new belt, wait for money to pour in, click your new belt a.s.o.

18933157.review:
I am a big fan of logistic-puzzle games and thought that this might take the gameplay of Spacechem or Factorio in exciting new directions. Unfortunately, the logistics puzzles and business simulation don't really play off of each other well, and the game quickly becomes tedious. 

The two halves of the game don't play well together. The logistics lines are a little bland and mostly come down to twiddling the concentration of a drug up, then down, then up again to evolve its attributes and get them to the right concentration. This might be more fun if you could go whole-hog laying out a complicated production line, but the business side of things ensure that's generally unprofitable. Everything operates at just a 1:1 or 1:2 ratio, so there's no thrill of big, powerful throughput like you get with a massive Factorio setup or a speedy Spacechem reaction. 

The business level isn't that interesting, either. Your profit is dependent on the efficiency and margin of your manufacturing lines. Sometimes competitors will interfere by saturating your drug's market, which reduces your profits. Often, a competitor will beeline patent technology just to force you to replace your best drug every other year. That's just annoying. The business layer is also your chief source of waiting, as you twiddle your thumbs waiting for the next ingredient or technology to unlock.

The GUI is also a bit of a chore. You'll frequently be flipping back and forth between the "Ingredients" and "Cures" tabs to try to figure out what steps you need to evolve your drugs, which ingredients provide the desired attributes, and finally what concentration you'll sell it at, and whether competitors are saturating the market.

There are some clever things. Sometimes you will sell a drug with a bad side-effect profile just because it's not profitable to sell a more refined form of the drug. Or maybe your drug will be too effective and demand will go down, or maybe your one drug's side effects will drive sales for another drug. These are all twiddly little fringe cases, and they're not cause enough to keep me playing.

Playing Big Pharma and figuring out its intricacies is a lot of fun... at first. The stages and challenges are pretty samey, and the game gets pretty old really fast. If the game cost five bucks, I might have given it a thumbs up recommendation; at its current list price, it's twenty bucks too dear.

Big Pharma provides dozens of hours of gameplay... but you'll only really have fun for the first few. If you keep playing past that it'll probably be out of some completionist urge, you'll play well past the point you stopped having fun with it and you'll just end up resenting the game. Once you've figured out how the game works and you find yourself just fulfilling mission objectives, this should signal that the honeymoon period is over and you should put this game down and do something fun instead.

If price is no object and you're really drawn in by this game's premise (I was), consider buying this for a couple hours' worth of fun. Otherwise, this is a title you can safely skip.

18589684.review:
Interesting - Buy it on sale

Quick points are below - full review right here.

This game has some addictive qualities and will keep you interested for a time, but overall it lacks the full grasping power of other simulation / business games.  Your competition is supposed to be another company or group of companies, however, as long as you're turning a profit it doesn't really matter.  You are given objectives to meet and once you get the hang of it, they're pretty easy.  Your competition doesn't seem to affect much.  There are more punishing game modes (start with debt, etc) but honestly the reward of "winning" isn't enough to even contemplate another run through this game.

The biggest adversary in the game is the whole researching and combining platform.  There are maybe 12 things to research, so this has already become exhausting and a chore.  It just has to be done and there is no thought needed.  I've found myself "waiting" far too often.  One of the biggest draws for me for business simulations is the complete micro-managing which ensures you always have something to do, that does not apply to this game.

There is a puzzle element to this game that I'm not sure it needs.  It's more annoying than anything.  I suppose if you're really into maximizing space you could enjoy it but it's much easier to just buy a few expansion spots and build what you need in an empty space and not worry about it.  I think planning your factory floor would be more enjoyable if the inputs / outputs of your machinery were customizable.  As it stands you have 5 of the same machine on a line all outputting in the same direction and you just get a maze of belts.  It's asthetically unpleasant and tedious.

I don't know how many more times I'll play this game.  Maybe a few run throughs here and there.  I've had much more fun with smaller / cheaper sims like Game Dev Tycoon.

If / when the workshop comes to this game I think it will be worth a second look.  There are so many aspects of the game that I think the creative minds of the Steam community could expand upon.  As it stands now, its just repetitive and tedious after a few run throughs.

Pros
+ Minimally addictive / interesting
+ A bit challenging at first
+ Fun to make medicines (for a bit)
+ Compounding meds for the max effect is challenging and rewarding*

Cons
- Repetitive
- Not enough "research" and "exploration / ingredient" options
- Puzzle aspect not needed and detracts
- CPU adversary essentially meaningless
- *Tarnished by the 12 same machines and room full of belts required to do it

Not recommended at current $25.

18180741.review:
This game does everything right.

It's an easy puzzle game wrapped into a good, challenging and fun manager game. It's charms and graphics are heavily leaning on THE definitive medical game of all times - Peter Molyneux's Theme Hospital.

So it has the looks, it has some of the charm, it has the management down and once you play a couple of games you will find that the AI scenarios (it comes with like 50 scenarios and also a very detailed custom scenario editor with import/export functionality) are a shark tank of competition, that reacts to your productions, aggressively researches and uses patents to shut down your profitable products etc.

The research is great. I can have fun and build a working company on any tech level, but I really want all of the technologies and cool gadgets as soon as I can get'em. The same thing happens with ingredients. You get the lore of sending some great explorer out into the wild, when in reality you are getting steady supply create relations with your impport seller to further be able to renegotiate prices in our favor. Their outfits don't reflect that mission, hehe.

The game is somewhat easy to learn. The tutorials should be played before going on to  other scenarios, or else you wouldn't know what you were doing. Once you do know though, the puzzle aspect of the game becomes even more intriguing than the eco manager for which you took it at the time of purchase.


TL:DR;

Get this game. Cute looking hard to master fun puzzler wrapped into a brutal economy managing game.

Are you going to cure a disease and destroy your own market for the medicine? Because that's part of the simulation, too.


This game does EVERYTHING right. It's addictive fun with high replayability and hard challenges.

18168788.review:
Big Pharma is a logistics min/max puzzle game mixed with a lightweight market simulation.  You'll make decisions regarding the quality of your cures vs. the strength of their side effects vs. the profit margins you get for selling them vs. the randomly-generated sized and shaped warehouses available to build in.

To go along with this, you'll have to work through a Research tree to gain access to better equipment and new ingredients as well as many ways to discount the various costs and/or efficienices in the game.  The better equipment is needed for making higher-end cures as well as making cures with less overall machines that might require more creative conveyor belt routing.  Some machines do take more turns to complete an action so now I need to build another conveyor line going this way and then bring them back together over here and then I just need to...  ahem...  

There's also an Ingredients tree where you'll send explorers to various places to unlock the ability to cure other diseases.  Some of these ingredients have special catalysts that you'll need to use to upgrade other ingredients.  Upgrading lets you develop cures for the more difficult and expensive diseases to treat.  All ingredients have side effects though that can vary widely - adding another layer of difficulty.  Inactive explorers will help you reduce the costs of your ingredients as well so you can bring up your profit margins without having to sacrifice a cure's quality because that stupid jerk other company is stealing my marketshare and my patent won't finish for another three months and staying in the green is tough right now so I just need to... ahem...

The game's main story mode has a really great variety of challenges to play through.  The tutorial levels are a spot-on introduction to the game and do a good job of preparing the player for the regular game.  The difficulty does ramp up pretty quickly between the columns - especially when there are additional competitors in the game.  Some of the levels are really straight-forward and you'll knock them out in no time flat.  Other levels are like trying to eat frosted mini-wheat cereal without milk, for lunch, while sprinting across the Sahara Desert being chased by whatever crazy hallucinations the sun poisoning has developed because writing this review is going on too long now so I just need to... ahem...

18017937.review:
[table]
[tr]
[th]Disclaimer: the key was provided to me for reviewing[/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

According to description, Big Pharma is a game about creating medicine recipes and selling them for profit. But it focuses more on production process then profit. It is safe to say Big Pharma is a game about creating an efficient production line to achieve your (scenario) goal. 

The game has a tutorial, but instead of (usual) series of interactions, tutorial itself is actually a guide-like-text in “tutorial scenarios”. If player can follow the text, it is quite helping and explains the details to a certain degree. Still, for the first few games, it is highly expected that the player will revisit these tutorials. It is also worth noting that the game expects the player to have “planning skills” because it never mentions how a good/efficient layout should be.

In this game, player is given a set of machines, and a number of ingredients. Every ingredient has one curing effect and one to three bad side effects (There are 4 effect slots on each ingredient). Each effect on an ingredient is active on certain “concentration range” and is most effective at a certain concentration. This concentration and activation of effects are the elements that create the base of the game. The player is expected to create a production line using the given machines, to activate the positive effect on an ingredient and create a medicine. Of course, bad side effects are present and are to be avoided. Curing effects on the final medicine increase the value and side effects causes it to lose rating resulting in losing value.

Illnesses and cure recipes are known, and when you produce a medicine, more advance version is unlocked, up to level 5 medicines. Although illnesses and cure recipes are known, ingredients are not. For each game, ingredients are randomly generated. Only things consistent among games are that each ingredient having only one curing effect and activation range of effects. From effect combinations to how much those effects change final medicine’s value is random. This increases replayability value. But it is also random for scenarios; therefore it affects the actual difficulty of the scenarios. One time the game may be too challenging and other time, it may be too easy.

Another randomly generated content is layout for production buildings. In each map, there are several (depending on the size of the map) partitioned buildings. The player is randomly given a partition at the beginning and buys the rest. The buildings and sockets are premade but layout of the buildings is random. Depending on the layout and starting position, the game may be annoying. Annoyance comes from shape of the buildings or the socket positions/count in a partition. Sockets are the points of entry/exit for the ingredients and medicines, on the walls of the buildings. Although there are at least 2 sockets in almost every partition, it can be more. Starting a partition with 4 sockets enables the player to have two production lines, without the need to but new partitions. Also a bad shaped building may prevent you to complete an advance production line required for the higher level medicines.

There are also exploration, research, patenting and “company management”. Research is the common knowledge. Player hires scientists to do research. Research unlocks new machines and some infrastructure projects such as cheaper machine prices or ability of exploring different types of lands. Exploration is the same thing as research but unlocks new ingredients instead. On a normal game, only the most basic machines and only 2 ingredients are available at the start. Rest is unlocked through researching and exploration. That said, researching and exploration are just a tab in the game and not the main focus. Same thing applies for the “company management”. Other than patenting process, company management is just an info tab showing player’s medicines, yearly revenue and profit. Also rivals’ basic info can be seen in company management. There is a research that enables to see detailed info about your rivals but it is pretty much useless. Patenting is what the name suggests. Patenting a medicine prevents the others from selling the same medicine for a limited time. The length of time depends on how much player chooses to spend on the patent.

Rivals in the game serve two purposes. One of them is to cause saturation because they use the same ingredient as the player and produce (mostly) the same medicine. This saturation increases the cost of ingredients and lowers the demand for a specific cure effectively lowering value of medicines. The other purpose is to patent medicine preventing the player to sell the same medicine. Of course the player has access to patenting after researching it too. This creates a nice “patent war” situation in the game, but patenting is pretty expensive and mostly not worth it until late game. 

As with all of the production themed games, most of the time in the game will be spend in paused mode. The player will try to make a good choice of ingredient-medicine pair to avoid side effects. After that, he/she will spend an equal time to position each machine in a way that they will occupy the least space. Since it is the nature of the game it is not a bad thing. Still, it is worth noting that machines can only be rotated in 4 directions and belts (connections between the machines) can’t be multi-layered (although they can be crossed and it mostly works well). These limitations may annoy some people, but also some “puzzle people” may welcome them because it gives the production a puzzle feel.

The interface is very well designed and the player is never lost in it. It has a futuristic design and goes well with the game. The sound effects of the game are nice and do not bother the player. But the game is a bit quiet. It needs a few more soundtracks.

Finally, a personal note: Everything in the game is sold back at half the original price. Especially at the beginning, you  may struggle with the design and make lots of mistakes. Buying and selling the belts will cause you to lose lots of money. To prevent this, plan and imagine the whole process in your mind, put all the machines first and then put the belts. It is also possible to get the “free belts” mod from the official site.

[h1][b]Pros:[/b][/h1]
[b]+ Simplistic:[/b] All menus and tabs are cleverly put together in a clear and simple manner.
[b]+ Good Formula:[/b] Game elements go well together.
[b]+ Fluent gameplay:[/b] There is nothing to get in the way during interaction with objects and interface.
[b]+ Mod Support:[/b] It does not support workshop but has a separate mod support.

[h1][b]Cons:[/b][/h1]
[b]- Randomization in Campaigns:[/b] This results in the campaigns becoming too easy or too hard.
[b]- Crammed Buildings:[/b] Sometimes building designs are too narrow or weirdly shaped and they do not allow a good production line.
[b]- Feels Repetitive:[/b] Although some of the content is randomized, after a while, the game feels repetitive due to its focus on production. This may be a deal breaker for some people.

[h1][b]Verdict:[/b][/h1]
If you think this game as a production tycoon game -as I did- it is well made (considering this is developed by a one-man-company). Overcoming the challenge to get rid of the bad side effects and creating a high rating medicine gave me enough satisfaction, so I recommend it. But because it focuses on production, it may be insufficient for some people.

[i][b]P.S: As a rule, I won't comment on price tag. Everyone has a different opinion on whether it is worth the price tag or not. So it is up to you to decide.[/b][/i]

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

[i]Edit: Fixed some typos[/i]

The main challenge is in laying out your production lines - making them as efficient as possible so you can squeeze more machines and manufacture more and complex cures in the limited factory floor space given to you.

Have you ever played an RTS where you get really immersed in building the perfect base, but every new level throws away your hard work and forces you to start again from scratch? Big Pharma is like a distilled version of that. 

It has 35 levels, all of which start you near the bottom of the tech tree. Pretty much every level will start the same - 10-20 minutes of building low-level supply chains, trying to get a profit while you wait for research to unlock. To make matters worse, building the supply chains is actually really tedious as you have to jump through the menus to research each stage of the process before you build it. You're constantly fighting to make a profit, and many of the levels have time limits. 

Don't let my high playtime fool you - I was afk for a lot of that. Big Pharma is only good for about 3 hours. After that, there's just too much tedium and not enough fun.

17929591.review:
Big Pharma...
I need to say two things about the game at the start:

1. The game is REALLY good, if you like repetitive puzzles with some niche changes over the cause of alot of different challenges pre-set by the game. It also has some sort of custom games mode - I have not touched on it so there might even be infinite amount of games you can play.

2. The game itself doesn't try to make you interested in playing more of it. It is a game that you pick up and play and then put down again - it doesn't have a character to it that makes every drug/medicine you make unique in its own flavour. You basically just try to figure out how many positive things you can put on a single thing and sell it.

Do I recommend the game? No. The game has an artificial longevity that is repeated in the same pattern over and over and over again. There simply is nothing 'unique' about each challenge you do since you will still build the same machines in every playthru' even if in different ways and shapes - they are still the same.
Same thing with the drugs... you need to compete against a competitor's painkillers? Then here's your one ingredience with a side effect - now make it good. Rince and repeat.

The game has replayability in the fact that all of the side effects and beneficial effects are random to some degree but like I said before, you are still building the same machines over and over again. Nothing happens except your own fuck-ups which some people find intriguing and I do too... in competitive games, not in games that makes me want to think and figure out what to do next.

And this game doesn't really do anything to try and challenge you - there are some mechanics like patents which can make you lock out your competitor's drugs for some time and they can do the same to you but, mechanics like those are just infurating when dealing with an AI where as these mechanics have a place in games when you are able to screw over one of your friends; you are able to get a reaction from them.

Overall the game is brilliantly made but doesn't do a whole lot with it. I bought it for 18,39€ where as I think the game's value would be around 9,99€ to 12,99€ - consider it when its on a sale but AVOID IT AT FULL OR NEAR FULL PRICE!

17920958.review:
The game focuses on setting up the production lines - it really isn't a business sim, but I don't think the game suffers because of it. Combining ingredients to get the desired effects, working within the confinements of your factory - there is plenty to think about. It can be very satisfying to tweak a production line to operate more efficiently, or to engineer out one of the pesky side effects. Probably do to my inability to think ahead, I'd have to re engineer my plans to overcome an obstacle I didn't anticipate. Researching better equipment opens up more options to formulate your products.

On the first advanced scenario, money was much tighter and the game provided a tense challenge. Sometimes competing against the AI feels arbitrary, maybe because they're mostly just messages that pop up. I don't feel like they're going through the same process as me. They are effective though - I would curse them when they patented a cure that was on my production line and they provide for some interesting moments.

My two main wishes are more fast forward levels and an online leaderboards so I can chase my friends' scores. Another nice touch would be to have a 'random' setting for each parameter when setting up a custom game. Many times games are more enjoyable if the player doesn't know quite what to expect and have to adjust their play once they discover what's going on.

I've read some people's complaints about the amount of content included in Big Parma and I don't get where they're coming from. There are many scenarios, taking hours to complete. Setting up a custom game offers more play for those who want it too.

So, if you enjoy setting up and tinkering with production lines, my guess is that you'll like Big Pharma. My full review can be [url=http://www.oneguytoomanygames.com/2015/09/big-pharma-review.html]found here.[/url]

17915956.review:
My fear in purchasing this was that I'd be bored of it in 5 minutes.  I'm glad to say that I was wrong.

Don't be fooled by the simple, clean UI---Big Pharma is a surprisingly deep simulator where the logistical puzzle of placing machinery to assemble your drugs is the least of your worries.  For me, the real difficulty of the game was interacting with the drug market, where you must balance drug prices, market saturation & also keep an eye on what your competitors are doing (if they're importing the same ingredient as you, for example, that ingredient may become oversaturated & its price will rise, hurting your bottom line).

You can flood the market with a side effect-laden drug for some quick cash if you want, but consumers will eventually figure it out & punish you as your cure rating drops & your drug starts losing money.

My only criticism of the game so far is that it lacks a planning stage where you can lay out your production lines in advance.  I had to repeatedly switch between the Ingredients & Cures tabs to work out how to develop a level 3 cure, and keeping track of the machines that I needed quickly became overwhelming.  In the end, I'd go to the Production tab to place a couple machines, then back to the Ingredients & Cures tabs to figure out what machines to place next.

A planning stage that tells you the concentrations/catalysts of imported ingredients (from the Ingredients tab), how to get to the cure (from the Cures tab) & the concentration/catalyst of the drug as it exits each machine in the planned line would be incredibly useful.  Then click a button to commit the entire thing, and you're done.

Also, when I'm deciding which machines to upgrade, it'd be very helpful to know how many of that machine I have across all my production lines.  For now, I can scan the lines to get a rough idea, but this is another example of mental gymnastics that the game could eliminate.

Big Pharma is a game that I wouldn't hesitate to pick up on sale.  I'll be following this one for sequels/expansions.

(This review was for version 1.00.04 of the game.)

17886699.review:
Big Pharma is obviously a business management sim, but it has some unique things going for it that distinguish it from other types of business management sims and give it a unique hook.

First let's discuss the normal business management aspects. You run a company that makes drugs, and there are essentially three areas of the company you have to manage. The first is that you need the space and the equipment to make the drugs, which means you will need to spend capital to purchase floor space and then you will need to spend more capital to purchase machines to go on that floor space that are used to make your drugs. (There is a LOT more complexity to this part of the game, but we'll get into that later.) The second area is research, which is pretty much just an unlock tree. You pay an initial flat rate to hire a scientist and then also pay each scientist by the hour. The more scientists you have on payroll, the more quickly you'll rack up research points, but that obviously gets expensive, so you need to balance with your income. Research unlocks new machines, new shipping methods, access to new drug recipes, ability to file patents on your recipes, and more. The third area is exploration, which is a tree similar to the research tree. In this area you pay a flat rate to hire explorers and then also pay them by the hour. You deploy your explorers to search jungles, deserts, oceans, etc for new or rare ingredients. By discovering new ingredients with new properties, you have access to new recipes that can be used to make a variety of new drugs. Explorers also have their own research points which you can spend to reduce the purchase price of ingredients and reduce your cost of materials.

These are the basics. Know that you will always have rival companies that are manufacturing and selling drugs in competition with you, and if the rival company's drugs are of a better quality than yours, they can eat up your market share (i.e. you will make fewer sales and earn less money due to your competitor stealing your customers). In the early modes and difficulties, competitors are a breeze to deal with. They can be more of a menace in later modes, though, for sure.

Okay, so what is the unique hook? The unique hook lies in purchasing floor space and machines and then assembling production lines. It is a complicated PUZZLE. Bear with me, because this gets a tad complex. Every ingredient you have to work with has four effect slots, and those four slots are filled with effects. The slots can either contain a curative effect, a negative effect, or simply be empty. The easiest ingredients to work with tend to have one curative effect and one negative effect. The more difficult ingredients have one curative effect and three negative effects. In addition to these effect slots, each ingredient also has a CONCENTRATION value that can be anywhere between 1 and 20. The higher the number, the higher the concentration. Each of the effects in the four slots has a random concentration interval assigned to it, and the effect is only ACTIVE if the concentration falls within that interval. For example, if the ingredient has the curative effect SOOTHES COLD that is active between 11-14, and the negative effect CAUSES CONSTIPATION that is active between 5-12, and the default concentration of the ingredient is 12, then THAT means that both effects are active in the ingredient, so you have to put the ingredient through a machine that will change the concentration so that the curative effect is active and the negative effect is not active. So if you change the concentration to 13, it is still within range to soothe colds, but it will no longer cause constipation. Get it? Still with me? It gets even crazier.

Okay, so obviously there are machines that can change the concentration value of an ingredient to alter the effects. But sometimes you have ingredients with three negative effects and it is literally impossible to deactivate all of the negative side effects, so then what do you do? Well, there are also machines that can shake up the order of the effect slots, and machines that can swap effects between two ingredients. So if you're clever, you can swap negative effects out and positive effects in. In some situations, you can even create super drugs that have multiple positive effects! The problem is that it can require a lot more machines to make these crazy drugs, which is not only more expensive to purchase the machines, but each machine also has a per-use cost as well, so it is in your best interest to have as few machines as possible. UGH. DECISIONS.

There are other ways to deal with negative side effects as well. For example, you eventually learn that not only does every effect have an active range, but every effect also has a "sweet spot" number, which is a specific number between 1 and 20 where the effect is 100% effective. So you can research your own drugs to find the sweet spots and improve your drug quality, which is important so that your competitor doesn't steal your buys with better quality drugs. And of course there are some interesting technologies you can unlock that don't really pertain to concentrations or effects but are still highly useful in other ways. There is really A LOT in here to learn and figure out.

Oh, and don't forget that you actually have to manually place each machine on the factory floor, rotate it, hook up the conveyor belts yourself, etc. Sometimes you have enough funds to set up a production line for a new drug, but you're out of floor space because you built too many huge production lines and you can't fit the new one in there. (Discontinue a line of drugs to make room for a new one? DECISIONS.) So there is also a spatial puzzle element of using the fewest machines possible, laying the conveyors to actually complete the circuit, arranging your machines and production lines in such a way that it doesn't get in the way of future building and/or allows you to upgrade or expand the current production line later as new ingredients become available.

There are lots of different difficulties, modes, and objectives to play. There is even a sandbox mode where you can get all machines, all tech, and are given infinite money, so you can experiment with the machines to figure out what all of them do. (Some people may be confused about how the mixer works at first, so having a safe place to test and observe it is helpful. Combining the mixer and shaker is an advanced gameplay strategy that is difficult to understand or use without a bit of practice and experimentation, so sandbox mode helps with that as well.)

Mods are available from the dev if you want to change up certain aspects of the game. For example, some people (including me) don't think it makes much sense that by default it is impossible to move conveyor belts without selling them and rebuying them at a loss, so you lose money for just correcting/moving conveyors (which is not the case with machines). So there is a mod to make conveyor belts free, which I recommend. (Though what they should have done for best balance, IMO, is just make the buy/sell price the same.)

Tutorial is well done. It is very hands on, but also easy to skim through quickly for those who have little patience and just want to get down to business (i.e. me).

Highly recommended for business sim lovers---especially if you like the idea of having some headscratching and puzzling thrown into the mix. You REALLY have to plan with this one.

This...is not the game I was expecting. However, it does what it *does* do very well.

It lies at the midpoint of real-time strategy and play-at-your-own-pace. 
It's very quick to start a game once you've done the tutorial, to begin making money. At that point, you start to work on a more complicated drug, researching machines and ingredients and continuing to make money. Eventually, you work on a greater drug. 
Laying it out requires planning--the game pauses so you can do that without losing time or money. It's very challenging, but in the way that requires you to think about what you're doing. It is not a game you play in bits and pieces--it is, however, the kind of game that's easy to learn and challenging to master. Getting the right cures, side effects, and concentrations to end up with the most profitable drug requires patience and spatial planning--and maybe a notebook and pen to keep track of everything.

Great fun, though. Pretty sure I played for almost two hours after I meant to go to bed.

This game is a sort of mini puzzle game encased in a shiny cover.

The major challenge in the game is to rotate buildings to create an assembly line of drugs, while keeping in mind that the structures can only be rotated, not flipped. (that, while often annoying, is a huge part of the challenge)

17861329.review:
I would be wary of reviewers that invest 5 hours or less into this game. The Advanced Mode's machines, along with the Centrifuge from Intermediate, radically increase the ways in which you can manipulate ingredients. It's also much harder to make and maintain a large profit, especially since competitors play a much greater role in the Advanced Mode. You'll need to start utilizing some hidden optimization tricks involving things like the packer or crossing belts with machines that have a cycle time greater than 1. So while dead-simple machine placement will get you through the Beginner and some of the Intermediate Scenarios, reaching Master in the Advanced Scenarios requires a lot more thought.

The negative reviews for this game have some merit, but the game doesn't promise anything more than it delivers. What this game does, it does very well: designing and optimizing production lines, anticipating what the market for a drug will bear, deciding what ingredients and machines to research or upgrade, all while balancing a budget that is very tight early and expands greatly over time. It's a beautifully-animated game that presents a relaxed puzzle atmosphere and gives you almost all of the information you'll need up-front.

Let's get some things out of the way, though. Sick people are abstractions, which is honestly what I'd expect from most Pharmaceutical companies. The larger the market for a cure, the greater the relative price and the more of that cure you can produce without tanking the price. The market can increase or decrease as a result of random world events, increase naturally over time for infectious diseases, and decrease as people are cured. A cure that's particularly potent will fetch a much higher price, but you may eventually be left without a viable market for that product.

The available cures and how they're upgraded are static. The starting concentration of an ingredient has a fairly narrow range based on the range of the Level 1 cure. The number of plots available for purchase, and the sockets within each building layout, are predetermined. On the other hand...The ingredient order is random, side effects are assigned semi-randomly, the building layouts you get are random, and the market for each cure is random within a small range. This can make or break the profitability of several cures, but the Level 1 cure of every starting ingredient is profitable and smart research choices can dig you out of some terrible early setups. Even a terrible cure can fetch a profit, although it can be much lower than you'd get from a perfect cure.

Anyone who says that the Competitors are pointless was playing on one of the easier difficulties. The competition presents a real challenge in Advanced Mode, as you have 3 competitors that all have the same early options that you do. Different AI companies prioritize different things, but they'll usually go for the more profitable cures and cures that can fetch high ratings (ie, no side effects). You have to be smart with your market choices in Advanced because the AI will very quickly oversaturate and tank the price for several cures. Anticipating what your competition will do is a big factor in your success. Patents in particular can really help you or really screw you over in the short-term, although they're fairly easy to work around, but you can do the same thing to the AI. Mucking with the AI's profit margins can really slow them down, giving you a chance to reach (and patent) the very high-level cures before they get a chance to ruin your market.

Sometimes you can make just plain bad choices, but usually there's okay options and really great options. There's almost always something you can optimize more if you put thought into it, and if you're shooting for a certain level of revenue or profit you'll be shifting around production lines a lot. I used to hit patches where I'd just need to wait, but now patch 1.01 added a much-needed 5x speed option!

Personally, I love this game. The progression has a level of predictability that may put some people off, but the random elements that people keep complaining about actually keep things fresh.

17843760.review:
Big Pharma is a ...Well, lets just say it outright, it's not a game about being a large scale megacorporation producing a massive amount of drugs and cornering the market. It's not a simulation of medical pills and pharma companies, and it certainly is not a game about the overall management of such a company or the simulation of such a thing.

It makes promises that it can not keep. You will get little strategy, severely abstracted simulation, and very limited management. 'Big Pharma' is not about anything big at all.

Instead, it is a small scale game that is essentially a puzzle about optimising chains of machines to produce a desired output, in a randomised building area of random size, with random ingredients that have random effects. If you like that, then good for you. You will probably enjoy this one, but for the rest of us who are after the other 'features' it proclaims to have..

The simulation is basic to the point where I wonder if it is a simulation at all. Diseases have a set number of sufferers or a set cycle/increase of sufferers and your management is limited purely to the supply lines, machines, and conveyor belts. Everything else is abstracted to the degree that I wonder why it was even included in the game, and many times adds nothing except a timer you need to wait on before you can continue working your belts.

The challenge, and main gameplay is more alike a puzzle.
Fit machines in the (random) building you have to have your (random) ingredients produce an optimal effect for maximum profit. Nearly all the gameplay is about optimising your conveyor belts and machines, which will be frustrating to you because the machines come only in one form with 4 facings. You can not make a symmetrical and effective supply line, and conveyors can not go over or under eachother. You get a limited amount of (Randomly placed) input/output areas to connect to, and often you will not have space for just about anything more than a basic machine.
Employees never have to walk in, out, or do anything in your building, they are merely an animation that is part of the machine. Research and exploration happens somewhere else. You never see your scientists or explorers except in a menu where you send them out.

If this game was only purely the production tab, was honest about its size and content and somewhere between 5-10 dollars, then it would be great. But as it currently stands I just can not reccommend it for its price. 
The conveyor belt optimising puzzling is nice, and I will likely play it a few more times just for that, but that is all there is to the game. There is no 'improving the lives of millions', there is no 'getting rid of disease', there is no real management or simulation of a 'pharmaceutical conglomerate' here. The challenge scenarios are jokes, the rival corporations are jokes, and the whole 'business sim' part that it talks about in the "About This Game" part of the store are jokes.

This is a conveyor belts puzzle with shiny graphics, get it for that if it is ever at a 75% or even 50% sale, but as long as it stays above 10 euro/dollar, I recommend avoiding it.

Thumbs up for this one, one of the better management/puzzle games released recently!

17818352.review:
Big Pharma is a fantastic management and simulation game. It's an usual subject to be managing, but now that I've played the game I'm surprised that it took this long for someone to think of it!

The game is a great balance of logic puzzle (in the form of making profitable drugs), business (deciding when to expand, when to invest, when to do nothing), and simulation of the pharmaceutical industry. I played this when it was first released in beta and it is a LOT better since that point, so if you read about the previous releases and weren't sure I'd suggest looking at a more recent review before deciding to buy. It's a great example of an early access game doing what you would hope: improving in the run up to release and being a better product when it gets there.

Positech has a great history of supporting and developing games post-release, and I look forward to playing this game for a long time to come with more and better things to do in it.

17818281.review:
I was worried that Big Pharma could turn out to be either too "casual" (like many cheap "tycoon" clickers), or too messy (like games that pretend to be serious, but just throw a bunch of random events at you at increasing pace - Theme Hospital, I'm looking at you). Luckily, that's not the case.

   There's far enough depth to raise the game well over the "casual" category. At the same time, its elements are completely transparent, so it doesn't overwhelm you with complexity. It could rather overwhelm you with opportunities. If you enjoy putting your brain to some work, this is a game a doctor would prescribe.

 Shortly, it perfectly touches the same strings that was touched by good old tycoons you are fond of, adds a surprisingly relevant puzzle element, and flavors the mix with good city sim's spirit of careful planning & continuous improvement. For details, look below.

PART 1. MAKING DRUGS
   Your goal is to create medicines and make money of them. A complex, profitable medicine usually consists of several components. Making such medicine usually takes many steps: starting an initial mix from a single ingredient and processing the mix through the chain of machinery, changing its concentration and adding other components (in specific order and specific concentrations). Each ingredient has some positive and negative effects. Effects are not just simple "+" or "-": during different processing, each effect could become stronger or weaker, or changed to another, or be removed at all. A mix of several ingredients, as you can guess, is even more complex and could end as many various intricate compounds.
   
   So, making your products is not a straightforward task: there are many methods to make different pills for the very same illness, with various effectivity and side effects. Every production step costs money, so your new creations are usually a compromise between love for humanity and love for money. Plus, when you carefully planned all processing steps and finished your future production line design, you need to fit it into your precious factory space (which is sometimes a puzzle itself). 

   Plus, you start with a limited set of ingredients and the most primitive machines, so your first drugs are cheap and will not provide for too long. To advance into new delicious markets, you need to jump quickly into expensive research, which cripples your feeble cash flow. And when each of yourr products finally comes to market, there's another story to tell....

PART 2. MAKING MONEY 
   You can estimate the market size and common price level of drugs for specific ilnesses. So, you can estimate your profits and risks of entering chosen markets, and pick out the best opportunity. You carefully look for needed ingredients and improve your technologies to make the product with minimal cost. Better quality can get you a hefty price bonus. But your product is not evaluated instantly. Only real applications show how good your creation turned out to be. So, only after time, statistics shows how effective the drug is, and how many side effects it caused. The price can fall dramatically if the medicine performs poorly, or causes far too many unpleasant experiences. Wrong formula? Your problem. Does demand for raw materials drive their prices up? Your problem. And don't forget you're not alone here. If your competitors saturate the same market with their products, and prices go down, guess what? You got it. Your problem.

   What's better: to reach after the tastiest pie with a risk that, in a year, every company will also be biting it? Or to look for stable but safe haven in a sector no one is looking at? To rush into selling an untested formula on industrial scale to make some quick money? Or to test all effects in detail and get the best product and ideal production line that will feed you for years? To flood the competitor's market with cheap alternatives to cut its profits (cause I can, baby)?  Or to use the same precious factory space for a new experimental drug? Your choice, and... yeah, your problem.

    "5 hours of gameplay" reviewers usually stop at, or even before, this point. People with more patience realize, unexpectedly, that Easy scenarios pack is a well-hidden tutorial extension, and that single "competitor" actually was a yawning guide in disguise.

PART 3. MAKING ENEMIES
   When you move to second scenarios pack, dusty gnomes inside your PC are finally convinced that you got used to the rules, and things start to get serious. 
   
   The whole new dimension of opportunities: research tree is exploded twice. Equipment which no one has shown you before. New level of formulas you can't even imagine creating without a pen and a paper. Vast number of ways to go. Tremendous amount of things to look into.
   
   The whole new level of warfare: margins are thinner. Side effects' combinations are more sophisticated and widespread. Rivals that, you know, look smart, have different characters and can painfully stab you (and each other) in the back. Wow, now I can patent drugs! What, now THEY can patent drugs?!
   
   All news are a news from a battlefront. Every day is an exhausting race for future riches and fierce dogfight for scarce resources of today. So, do you enjoy to put your brain to some work? Say again? Sorry, wasn't listening. It's all about stress. Got problems with my Prozac production. The composition is a joke. So, what were you saying?

17801196.review:
Big Pharma is a great game for everyone who likes planning, tweaking, optimization. 
Your task is to manage a pharma corporation by producing and selling drugs. To get the job done, you´ll find your self searching for the required ingredients that can be processed and transformed into almost endless varieties as you increase or decrease concentration, add ingredients to produce new treatments and upgrade their effects. 
To make things more difficult, almost all ingredients have side effects that you may remove, weaken, avoid (by manipulating concentration) or just accept as a necessary evil - but beware, strong side effects will lower your drug rating and value. 

To make matters more complicated, your factory equipment cannot be placed neatly into straight assembly lines - each machine type has its own layout and creating complex chains will indeed be a puzzle game. And things usually don´t stay in place once you add new options to your arsenal - I find myself frequently redesigning my factory layout to optimize it according to the newly unlocked machines (which you can research). 

All the while, different scenarios and settings require you to work towards a variety of different objectives, from just making cash to delivering a super-drug with high value.


To sum it up:  This game makes you think! If you like complex problem solving tasks, this is definitely your game.

17800524.review:
Big Pharma is essentially a game where you are able to spend your money on parts such as "evaporators" and "dissolvers" in order to create new medications that will essentially give you more money, to spend more parts, to get more money, to spend new parts etc. This game has an endless cycle of "spending money on parts" and "gaining more money", just like the games "Rollercoaster Tycoon" and "Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?". Other than giving specific goals to reach, such as gaining $1,000,000 in revenue in 10 years, this game really has no point other than to keep you in the "endless cycle", which is why I cannot give it a "thumbs up".

However, If you are the type of person who loves these kinds of games, then I will tell you that there are many aspects to consider, including:
-Research
-Finding new Ingredients
-Getting Loans when your bankrupt (which many games do not allow you to do)
-Upgrading standard Migraine Pills to something even better
-Upgrading Equipment
-Competitor Companies (AI companies, not multiplayer)

Even though Big Pharma is not my preferred cup of tea, it may be of interest to people who like the game I just described above.

Happy Gaming
-Matt

17798780.review:
One of the best management simulators to come along in ages and ages.

There's a lot of complexity here and there's a bit of a learning curve, but the tutorial covers the bulk of what you need to know. Unfortunately, the format of the tutorial feels pretty lazy to me and it suffers for that. Namely, it's rendered almost as an in-game manual. The game really needed an overlay-style tutorial rather than "OK, now click this widget, whose location on screen we will now describe in words instead of just pointing at it." But that's seriously the only criticism of this game I've got and it's easily fixable if the developers wanted to put some time in on it. It's also an issue that you'll quickly forget about once you start getting the hang of things.

So basically, your job is to make drugs. Drugs need to cure things. Ideally with as few side-effects as possible. But critically, you need your drugs to be profitable. Everything you do to remove side-effects or analyze the ideal mixture and concentrations for your drug ingredients introduces processing costs, which lowers your profitability. Meanwhile your competitors are making drugs that may target the same conditions. If their drug has fewer side-effects, demand for your drug will drop, and with it, the price you can charge for it. Suddenly you have to go back and do all the work you maybe skipped in the interests of profits because your terrible drug was properly recognized in the market as terrible. Unless of course, you patent your drug. Competition sucks. Nobody wants competition.

You also have some interesting processing challenges around parallelizing the right parts of your pipeline while working within spacing and arrangement constraints. Actually, that's pretty much the core of the game. It's probably one-third budget management and two-thirds arrangement puzzle game that heavily informs the budget management aspect (bad arrangements are unprofitable).

I'll be playing this one for quite awhile.

Honestly, I could also see this game as being quite workable in a multiplayer format and I think multiplayer might be pretty fun. Since the game is moddable, it might even be possible for the community to supply that functionality. Who knows?

Might not be worth €20, but I'd certainly recommend to pick it up during a sale.

17795044.review:
This game was a little bit of a surprise..  I don't usually get much into tycoon type games, though I have fond memories of Theme Hospital from a few years back, and I guess Rollercoaster Tycoon, so my experience isn't great to compare this to others in the genre.   That being said, I find this game a great deal of fun.

There are two core elements to the game;  a Logistical puzzle, and, a decent strategic/business simulator.  I'll cover these separately.

The first part is what you mostly see in the pretty screenshots - you need to construct assembly lines that transform raw biological substances (insect parts, plants, etc) into finished pharmaceuticals.   There are a good number of different medicines you can manufacture and each one has vastly different requirements.  You need to purchase a variety of machines to transform the product as it moves along the belt from the 'in window' to the exit.   Some machines strengthen effects and some dilute them.  Other machines are used to combine two ingredients, to analyze a finished drug, to modify or rearrange effects, and to package the final product.  All of these machines have different 'in' and 'out' slots that will need to be matched up via conveyor belts in the correct order.   At first this can be a little daunting and frustrating, especially when you attempt to 'upgrade' a drug to a more powerful version, and some trial and error is required.   That said, it's great fun once you learn the basics, and quite rewarding when you smooth everything out.

The second part of the game is the business sim.  This is probably standard fare for these types of games, but again I'm not experienced enough to provide a good comparison.  In order to succeed you'll need to carefully manage your expenses - buildings and expansions, machines, drug ingredients, research, and exploration all require money, and while you can take out loans, this will quickly sink you if you don't have steady cashflow coming in.   There are competitors who are trying to make a profit as well, and deciding which drugs will provide the best returns can be a challenge.  You must invest time and money into research in order to unlock better machines and make your existing ones more efficient.  You also must send explorers out to discover new substances that can be transformed or combined into new types of drugs.  Random events can have impact on supply and demand as well, so it pays to keep an eye on news popups.

There is a good tutorial, which introduces you to game concepts as you play so you don't get overwhelmed.  After that, a series of 'missions' of advancing difficulties keeps the game fresh.   I can't speak to the replayability of the game as I'm nowhere near completing the core missions yet, but I believe there Is a sandbox mode once you've mastered all the basics.  The missions themselves can take from 15 minutes to a couple hours, depending on the difficulty and how focused you are.

Big Pharma's art style can be described as cartoony and colorful.  It really reminded me of a less silly version of theme hospital, but aside from the graphics (and upbeat music) there aren't may other similarities between these two games.  One nice feature is the ability to 'paint' your factory - with various primary hues and patterns.  This could be useful to customize different product lines or processes on each line, or just pretty things up to your own tastes.

I recommend this to anyone who enjoys casual business sims and puzzles.  Big Pharma succeeds well at both, and I found it well worth the price of 24.99, though I was fortunate enough to get it on sale.

17795031.review:
I'll say this is one mind bending game.

Cons first:  
First the interface does need a touch up.  The GUI needs work to help navigate from cure start to cure finish along the lines of what you need to do.  At the moment you constantly have to switch between tabs in the GUI to determine the proper course of action to produce your product, fortunately you can pause the game.  It is a bit tedious to do so and I would like to see something more streamlined that allows for easier production of your cure.

Second, No multiplayer.  You do play against an AI.  The AI's production of similar products  will effect cure pricing and both you and the AI can issue patents to have sole ownership of a cure.  There are world events that dictate supply and demand so it would be great to have multiplayer for the same reasons.  Unfortunately in a multiplayer scenario there would have to be two requirements:  A: Make it turn based to get around the GUI issue, or B: streamline the GUI for faster recognition of steps.

That's it for cons that I see.

Pros:

Game runs very well.  The GUI does look great.  You really feel like a factory floor manager.
Nice graphics.  Everything moves flawlessly around your factory floor going from starting point to A>B>C>D>E sell (Sometimes more steps, sometimes less).
The game has an awesome puzzle base to it.  Not only must you solve on how to make your cures effective while mitigating side effects but you must also work out factory logistics to make your factory run efficiently.  Getting things to run efficiently is the harder part in my opinion, since you can pause the game to research your cure development steps.  
Modable, no need to say more.

All in all I really enjoy it.  It has the right amout of difficulty to frustrate the hell out of you and make you want to come back over and over to try to solve that pesky logistical problem so you can make as much money as possible.  Believe me I have quit several times in my short play time to give my mind the time to solve the problems while not actually sitting and playing.  Damn you money, I want more.

17767354.review:
It's a good game, but I can't give it a positive review.  The concepts are awesome and they're off to a good start, but the gameplay just doesn't deliver enough enjoyment.  The game's systems are very complex, and the main problem the game suffers from is the interface.  The information you need to find out in order to make effective choices is arranged in a very arcane and dispersed fashion.  This leaves you with two choices: 1) Play the entire game alternating between Play and Pause, and spend most of the game looking for information while Paused, or 2) Discover all the information you need AND engage in critical thinking while Playing, at which point, the situation will have changed so much that you need new information and a refinement of your original plan.

What this means is, the gameplay just doesn't deliver enough of a hands-on feel so that you feel real control over the game's systems, and over your chosen outcomes.  But it's one of those games that gives you enough tiny little dopamine-buzzers (Dings, music, sounds, green profit text, etc.) to fool you into thinking you're having a good time and keep you hooked.

But after you play for 4 hours, you're just left with kind of a "blah" feeling.

If they made the interface more concrete and less arcane, the game would have a better feel, ie. Player Input -> Logical Outcome.  Then I'd give it a better review.

6/10.

17757255.review:
Big Pharma is a tycoon-style game based around pharmaceutical development. It holds the isometric view of classic games like Rollercoaster Tycoon while being graphically sleek. As with its tycoon-style roots, it also contains puzzle elements as the equipment you must use act as puzzle pieces that you must fit together in a fixed amount of space.

[h1]So what makes this game appealing?[/h1]

Firstly, it's a management simulation game. If you're as big a fan as Rollercoaster Tycoon as I am, chances are you'll enjoy this game just on the style of the game alone.

As for how the levels are set up, there are several categories of scenarios each with their own set missions. These categories range from Beginner to Advanced difficulties, along with Quick Play and Crippling Debt categories, the last of which severely handicaps you if you're looking for a challenge!

When it comes to dropping into a scenario, the building space and ingredients you have at your disposal are completely randomized. This means you can start the game with a nice area to start building in, or perhaps a not so nice area. It also means that you can have ingredients that induce negative side effects or not. But no fear! You can buy more space with the money you have and discover more ingredients through exploring different biomes for new raw materials to make cures to illnesses with so overcoming a rough start is entirely doable.

Exploring for new ingredients is a must as well as researching new methods to manipulate the drugs to turn them into cures. The ingredient system works very well in my opinion. Sometimes you just have to change the concentration of the ingredient to make higher level cures but sometimes you also need to mix it just right with catalysts to make the drug a higher selling product which adds more layers of depth to production.

With all that, there are also competitors that influence the drug market in their own unique way that isn't the same each time you play. Competitors may release the same drug as you have, saturating the market with supply which brings the price of the drug down a little. So release patents to stop them and hope they don't do the same to you!

This game, while simple at its core, offers a great managing experience and varying levels of challenge even within each mission through three different win-states. The win-states are like a "Bronze, Silver, Gold" medal type system which rewards both casual and hectic play.

[h1]What may users not like about the game?[/h1]

If you’re like me that wants to try to perfect everything and max out the space you’re given? There's ALWAYS something that requires your attention, requiring you to be ready to do a whole list of things until you end up closing out of the game or pause it to take the dog for a walk. There's no real time to take a step back and admire what you create or take a breather. Even on the beginner levels there are always ways to enhance production, make new production lines, enhance ingredient discovery or research, etc. However, you can choose to take the game slow if you want; there’s nothing stopping you but the goals you set for yourself when you drop in!

Also just a note, this is one of those games that you need to play the tutorial to really get a good foundation on how to play.

If you're still indecisive, I've made a small video series of me playing the game trying to reach master level on the game. I jump right into it and explain how everything works and I believe you'll know if it's a game for you within a few minutes of skimming through gameplay.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEx3_SSiCgc

Aside from that, have fun making drugs that give people headaches while simultaneously cure migraines!
