17755528.review:
I've been playing this game since its early beta days back in June 2015. Big Pharma might look like your run of the mill tycoon game, but it is much deeper than that. 

The concentration system for drugs, the random ingrediant generation and robust AI compeditor performance (especially on higher difficulty levels) lends this to be a very interesting and *very* replayable game. Sure the random nature might mean that the available ingrediants are awesome in one game and suck in the next...but since everybody in the game plays with the same pool of ingrediants, the challenge is to make the most of what is available. 

This is also a part puzzle game as you try to figure out how to cram your more and more complex production lines into a limited space. It can be extremely satisfying to have nearly every square inch of an area filled to the brim with drug machinery humming with their various drug modifying operations. 

The tech tree is laid out in a logical but still strategic manner. Researching techs takes scientists and keeping scientists employed is expensive, so deciding which techs to go for in which order is important. Given the variable ingrediants each game, you aren't going to always want the same path down the tech tree each game. Not to mention you have to weight the options of leaving your scientists idle, which generates research points that are used to upgrade your equipment (making it cheaper to operate) or use them to research new techs, giving you access to brand new equipment or other discounts. 

If you are a fan of business tycoon games at all, this game is for you. It is absolutely worth the price of admission.

17755278.review:
So first off: this game has a lot of polish. this is a well-done game.  the UI is slick, the mechanics are new (to me) and interesting.

maybe I'm being too picky, but I take umberage with how they implemented the belts - and for a game that hinges on logistics, belts are important. they have frustrating logic, trying to 'predict' your intentions. Basically you should only be placing belts as the final step, and even then dragging from point A to B is the most efficent path, but not if you want to tuck into that space later - also if you're in a rush, you're more likely to place a t-junction that halts an entire  production line, and there is no attention grabbing 'hey you broke x'. I apologize for offering criticism without an alternative, but all I can think of is more fine-grained control.

if you like a good puzzle game / business sim with some depth (the ingredients and researching and upgrades are a nice touch) and don't mind looking past some frusting flaws (or are more forgiving/patient than I) then this could be hours of enjoyment for you.

as it is, 20$ for a game that will end with ME needing blood pressure medication? I'll pass.

17751446.review:
I have only played 8 hours of this game so i have not even experienced the entire content the game has to offer but i can say that this game is highly addictive, and highly recommended for all those who are fans of simulation/management games.

The aim of the game is to take ingredients and alter them in order to create cures for specific illnesses and then sell them to make money to make more cures etc etc.

The game has a very steep learning curve, especially in relation to the later tier drugs that involve mixing. Getting these to work in a fluid manner (maximising profits) is quite challenging and requires a lot of trial and error so i highly recommend after the tutorial loading up the mode which has all the research and drugs unlocked so that you can play around and learn how to create a fluid setup of the machinery and adapt to the different building structures (there are only a few so even though its completely random you will get familiar with each one eventually).

I did read alot of reviews before purchasing this game and a few mentioned the randomness of the drugs you recieve at the start of the game and size of the building being annoying/limiting the ability to play the game. However i dont think this is as much of an issue, the game seems fairly balanced and gives you plenty of time to complete scenarios regardless of the spawn. I can see the spawns being an issue if you are an achievment hunter who wants to complete all the levels on master (the time limit is much much less), however this can be worked around if you just restart the mission a few times so in my opinion the randomness is not a big deal for those who read those reviews and got worried that the game is broken.

I also especially like the addition of a "global economy" aspect in relation to the competing companies whereby you need to ensure that the drugs you make are better than theirs by fine tuning them or you will not sell as many units loosing you money or manufacture ones that the ai have not considered thereby creating your own monopoly of the drug (can also be done by patents).

Also a must have are the mods for this game, only ones i have found so far are the ones supplied by the actual Big Pharma website, they are very useful (example free conveyor belts).

Overall, great game, very challenging and i can see many hours of my life being eaten by it.

17744290.review:
Have played a lot of this game before it reached Steam. It has a very tycoon feel to it while being very puzzle like in the builds. It currently has 35 different challenge senarios that all have randomly generated buildings and ingredients with randomly generated possitives and negitives each time you start a new challenge so you can very much play the same challenge over and over and get an entirely different play through each and every time. The machines mechanics are for the most part well expained though there are some things that you learn by just doing. 

And say you don't like any of the scenarios or have beaten the master rank (basicly gold in a gold/silver/bronze rating system) of all the scenarios (which would take a long time to do even if your great at the game)  custom game has a ton of customization to it, choose anywhere from 0-3 competitors, 5-15 randomly generated ingredients, where you start with 2-5, how many catilist there are and their side effects, victory conditions of total revenue, operating profit, within x years, x products with atleast x profit or value or level, minimun cure rating, total products, and pay off loan, which you can combine in any fation, so say you want the winning condition to be where you have to have 3 pills that all make atleast $1,000 profit per pill produced all with atleast B cure rating within 15 years with no competitors, you can do that. You can also set what research you (and all competitors) start with and even what research is disabled in the game (so say you don't want anybody to be able to make patents you can disable patents).

Then you get into settings like map size, event frequency, loan interest rates, plot cost, research speed, scientist saleries, scientiest hire cost, explorer saleries and hire costs, analyzing speed, patent speed, patent cost, cure market size, cure profit margins, starting money, starting loan, ingredient prices, process costs, build costs, research point accrual speed, ingredient point accrual speed, cure rate, infection rate... and all of these things don't have just like 5 settings, they are all sliders that have many many settings even if its not good at informing that well (for example plot cost you could set to where it says low and the first land may cost $500, but then you set it again in low but slightly in a different slider cost and now it costs $480 or $620 for the first one.

Between the randomly generated buildings, the randomly generated ingredients, the number of custom challenges with 3 ratings that are fairly challenging to get the best rank on, and the sheer customability of custom games, you will find that this game is very replayable even doing the same challenge or even same custom game settings because even with the exact same custom settings the buildings and ingredients are randomly generated each time which also means what the competitors make which effects your profit margins also changes each time. And can be as challenging or easy as you want it to be. And even as quick or long as you want it to be depending on how you set all the custom game sliders and victory conditions.

17743825.review:
I've been playing Big Pharma via a non-Steam version and have been really enjoying it. I'd played at least a dozen hours before the 1.0 release and have been very please with how the developer has not only been regularly updating the game, but also responding to community inputs and making changes based on them.

I'd have to say that it's partly a puzzle game, in that you have to build assembly lines that require some planning and tinkering to fit them in the available space and also to spend as little money as possible. And you have to research more efficient (abet more costly) production machines that take up less space.

It's also a business sim, in that you buy resourses, process them and then produce a product. This is done very well in the game because you don't have to stare at spreadsheets, instead you can just mouse over the production lines or your company page and the appropriate info is right there. And it's very easy to understand where you are making and losing money, in fact I'd say that this game is one of the best examples of how to make a business sim right.

And the other nice feature that I like is that the game is composed of a number of scenarios/missions, most of which have three different levels of victory, and you don't have to unlock any particular mission to play any other of them. Plus there's also a custom game mode, where you can alter all sorts of criteria and conditions, and a free build mode where you can just make assembly lines and geek out on that.

The game is very polished and glitch and bug free. I very much recommend it.

17743704.review:
I jumped onto this while it was in beta and fell in love, I am happy to see it reach full release and look forward to play it again in a finished state.

This is kind of an unique game, it kinda is a tycoon game were you build production lines to create and sell drugs while also search for new ingredients and do research for more options and better machinery. The production line building is more like a puzzler were the challenge lies to make a space efficient and use a minimal amount of machines to reach your goals.

The ingredients you use have 4 "slots"  on them each with 1 curing effect and also 1-3 negative effects, stacked into the negative effects are also catalysts that are required for many cures to be upgraded. To top that off the ingredients also have a concentration wich ranges from 0-20 and different effects (both good and bad) are active at different concentration levels.

Altough the concept of the game is quite easy to understand, it can get quite complex as you advance and need to mix and match different ingredients while trying optimse the concentration levels for upgrades while simultaniously trying to run a full speed production with a minimal amount of machines usage for your super drugs. All this is done on limited space and "sockets" that you need to bring in ingredients and ship out the drugs.

The machines you use "never fits" wich adds a great deal of challenge while also giving a glorious feel of accomplishment once the line for your anaesthetic that cure aids, alzheimers and functions as a male contraceptive.

I highly recommend this game

Don't be fooled by the hours played, I've put in at least 30 hours in the beta phase (outside steam).

[h1]The good:[/h1]

17742400.review:
VERY well made game! I had a sneaky suspician that this was going to be a good game (from what I'd researched prior to its launch), but I was surprised to find that it was much better than I had expected.

See the TL;DR read section at bottom if you want just the quick notes.

I'm trying to keep the in-depth review as brief as possible, but it's very difficult...there's so much to say about this game.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[b]1. GAMEPLAY[/b]

You start, grow, and manage a pharmaceutical company. You control every aspect of it such as production lines, research and development, budget (purchases, importing ingredients, payroll, cost of production), meeting market demand, etc. This is a pharmaceutical tycoon game and it gives you plenty of options and features to run the business as you please or win a scenario as you please. 

Designing the production floor is like a puzzle...but I really hate using that word. It's not a puzzle game. You have to make use of the space you are given (which is a lot so far for me) and plan workflow, but it's much more than that. There are options upon options to consider  The game can be very complex at times, but it also allows the player to keep things simple if they so choose.

There are 8 Scenarios with 5 missions each. Some missions are specific, some are rather broad.  There's also a custom game feature and a free build option. Together, they allow the player to really play as they want. You can develop highly sophisticated medications or you can deal with simple production lines. It's entirely up to you!


[b]2. THE GAME IS POLISHED![/b]

Unlike many indie games, particularly with early access but not exclusive to them, this game is extremely...I mean extremely polished. Everything was very well thought out and organized. Key features were included yet nothing seems to exist that doesn't need to be. ALL the necessary fundamentals you'd expect are here (rare for many games today unfortunately), but many are done exceptionally well and are thus, quite noteworthy. 

Examples...

[olist]
[*]One of the best tutorials I've ever seen in a game - it comes in the form of sections and are repeatable (for those of us who sometimes take a hiatus from a game then return later but forget some of the key controls/mechanics). There are also more in-depth tutorial videos by the dev for those who prefer some serious explanation as to what is going on (most probably won't need it though). The tutorial not only gives you the basics and walks you through the steps (allowing you to learn by doing vs reading a wall-o-text in game), it gives you game strategies such as using dual pill printing and options for varying concentration effects). A lot of thought went into the tutorial here.
[*]Speed controls - should be standard in every game of this sort...but unfortunately many aren't including it. Pause, play, or speed up time here.
[*]Ease of controls - you can hold down key to drag belts and it will auto path and connect where you want. Middle mouse copies an existing machine for further placement, double click allows you to move an existing machine, right click sells a machine.
[*]Convenient linking from one page or pop up to a RELEVANT page or place in the game (such as a an alert for new ingredient having a link to take you to the Ingredients page for convenience if you so choose)
[*]Animations are very well done and relevant to what is happening (fun to watch)
[*]Aesthetic customizer - change colors of belts and floors, you can customize your buildings the way you want. 
[*]Contemporary design - very well done design with the gui and game assets. Details like in-game notices are done very well too (sliding from the side at top of page vs simply popping up in the middle of the page or displaying on the right hand side which is what most games seem to do).
[/olist]

Lastly, one of the biggest parts of polish which was noticed...was the lack of any bugs!  I am despearately trying to find some. I know some have to exist. But I so far, have failed to discover any. The game runs smooth and there are no bugs that break immersion or stop gameplay.

The dev did what most other devs do not do today it seems...he focused on QUALITY. He put a substantial amount of time into the game PRIOR to released. He focused on giving customers a QUALITY project to enjoy by making sure the details were there but also that the game works as it is supposed to. He demonstrated that he actually cares about his own game, his own work.

Novel idea huh? Give the players a quality product they expect to have?

[b]3. DEV ACTIVITY[/b]

First of all, this is the work of only 1 developer. He, like most devs used outside sources for assets (graphics, sounds, effects, voice), but 1 guy is the brain behind this game. Very few games can be pulled off successfully by a single dev and this one was.

He also is very active in his communication with customers (his own forum, social media, and here at the Steam forums). 


[h1]THE BAD[/h1]

I am still struggling to find something. I honestly am. I've not experienced anything negative about this game yet.

The only thing I can see wanting to change, is a part in the last tutorial which discusses maximum strength analysis and how to implement it to upgrade a medicine's rating. To me, that's a bit fuzzy. I tried to understand what was being described and how to pull it off, but didn't understand it. That could just be me though. Regardless, it does not prevent the mission from being completed. It just means the user, or me anyway, needs to ask for clarification on the forum.

[h1]SUMMARY / TL;DR[/h1]

High quality game, extremely polished, plenty of options and features, a lot of variation, NO BUGS (so far). This game will probably become one of the standards of quality that gamers will compare other games to (like many compare other ea games to Prison Architect or Kerbel).

In a sea of poorly designed games from devs who don't seem to either care about their products or have the knowledge to make them great...and with the current gaming community's frustration level at an all-time high due to the abundance of bad games and ripoffs coming out on Steam...let this game refresh your faith and trust in the industry as it is proof that high quality games CAN be delivered and some devs DO care about their project and their customers.

If you enjoy tycoon style games, do yourself a much deserved favor and GET THIS GAME NOW! You will not regret it (especially with Steam's refund policy of course - but you won't need it).

17741584.review: buy if you enjoy games like factorio, infinifactory and spacechem

17741176.review:
So I've been playing since the early access non-steam beta came out and I've put about 30 hours into this game before this release and I honestly have to say while I like the idea it has some really bad core problems that all stem from it's use of luck.

Basically this is a puzzle game with a enormous amount of randomness thrown into it and those are two things that rarely work well together. The game is more or less about completing scenario's with tiers of set goals and two months ago I made a rather long post on /r/bigpharmagame that explained why it's not done very good well overall.

The short version is basically everything you need is random. The amount of space you start to build in is random, the drug effects you start with are random, the effects on those drugs are random, the order you unlock new drugs is random, the products your competitors will make are random. The only non-random things are how much money you start with and your overall goal for the scenario. Which leads to many many MANY unwinnable situations, e.g; It's possible to play a scenario were you have to produce certain medicines within a certain time period and random chance will put the drug you need so far down the research list that there's no possible way to even get to it let alone produce anything with it before the time expires.

To put it into something that most people would understand; pretend your playing StarCraft 2 but the amount of SCV's you started with was random, so was the amount of vespene geysers, mineral patches and how much was in them.  With me so far? So YOU might start with 2 SCV's, 4 vespene geysers and 3 mineral patches, while your opponent starts with 10 SCV's, 2 vespene geysers and 20 mineral patches. Now ontop of that also make all the unit costs and research a random number as well. Do you see why this is bad now?

It's basically a requirement to restart a scenario over and over again til you get the space and favorable drugs you need if you plan on getting anything but the bronze completion. Even if you get a favorable start, you still might need to end up restarting anyway because you may have had 2 of the drugs you needed for the 3 pills you had to produce but sadly #3 is the very last one your explorers can find.

Overall it's what killed the game for me. If there was set drugs with set effects with set starting positions on the board then I wouldn't have had nearly any of the complaints I did. But overall you spend more time restarting then actually playing the game unless your content to bust your ass for bronze the whole way through, riding the waves of luck.

17739486.review:
I played dozens of hours of this game while it was in development and it's been one of my favorite games of the year! I'm happy to see it's now on Steam!

Big Pharma is a very unique game. It's best described as a tycoon/management game, mixed with a logistics puzzler or "product chain" puzzler, such as SpaceChem, Infinifactory, or Factorio. Your goal is to create and sell cures ranging from cough suppressants to cancer medicine. The creation process is done through a network of machines and conveyor belts that tinker and transform the potency of raw ingredients into the desired cures (often combating undesired side effects).

Often just figuring out how to make a good product is an excellent puzzle in itself, but it's made even more challenging by the ability to perfect the potency of a drug, mix multiple beneficial effects, and remove unwanted side effects. On top of that is a whole financial layer, including an ever-changing market of supply (how much raw ingredients cost) and demand (how badly a cure is needed), further complicated by the competition of rival companies who can drive up ingredient costs, compete for similar cures, and even try to patent certain drugs to prevent others from selling them temporarily. All this is mixed with a large research tree and an interesting procedurally generated list of unlockable ingredients that need to be researched and experimented with in order to advance your company.

Sound complex? It is! This game is not a casual experience. As a management game, it strives to be more similar to older "Tycoon" games of the 90's and early 2000's, where succeeding financially is a genuine challenge and there's very little hand-holding when it comes to how to get there. At the same time, the game is definitely in the same vein of puzzle games like the aforementioned SpaceChem; a production puzzle game with no single "right" answers, but millions of wrong ones. Arranging the differently shaped machines and placing conveyor belts is as tricky as trying to figure out the correct combination to make the desired product. But, like the best  of both of those genres, as hard as they are, Big Pharma is actually very easy to learn once you wrap your head around its new ideas, and the payoff is countless ultra-satisfying "I'm a freakin' genius!" moments. The most important thing to note? The tutorial is NOT optional for a new player, and since it's a bit of a wall of text, I imagine that might put some people off.

In terms of aesthetic, I absolutely adore the game. The music is absolutely perfect for the subject matter, the UI is one of the cleanest and most functional I've ever seen, and like most good factory-themed games, seeing your products  move down conveyor belts and through wacky machines en mass is an absolute delight.

My only worry with the game at the time of writing is that it might have released just slightly too early. For the most part it's fully functional, but there are still a few bugs here and there, and it felt like the balance of things like competitor productivity and patents were still trying to be worked out when the game was released. So far, I've found nothing remotely game-breaking and it's definitely more functional than many things released on Steam, but I'm sure it still could use a few patches (there's also whispers of modding support that might expand the game in the future).

Overall, Big Pharma is definitely my kind of game. I'd say it's a must-buy for anyone who likes production puzzlers like SpaceChem or Infinifactory, and a good buy for those who have fond memories of old Tycoon games (with a thematic boost to anyone who loved the game Theme Hospital). Those who want a more casual experience may want to look for something simpler, but for anyone for a great brain-straining puzzle and interesting management game, Big Pharma has your cure!

tl;dr
+ Great open-ended logistic puzzle gameplay
+ Lots of depth, with a good tech tree, many machines, and tons of cures and side effects
+ Procedurally generated factory layouts and randomized ingredients make each game feel unique
+ Great music and lighthearted aesthetic
+ Very challenging with many different ways to succeed
+ Interesting business simulation with fluctuating markets and competing companies, adds a new layer to the financial aspect of the game.
- Complexity may be off-putting; tutorial NOT optional
- Minor bugs, might still need a few balancing tweaks

17738988.review:
Having played this game in (pre-Steam) alpha and beta for over 150 hours I can say ... it's amazing!

So, what is it about?

- Create a perfect, smooth running production cycle
- Are you going for a cheap medication, try to appeal the mass-market, make a quick buck?
- Do you want to perfection it, research side-effects, minimize them and improve?
- Beat your competition by patenting the big cures? Maybe YOU are the guy curing Ebola, getting rich and famous?
- Research new ingredients, new cures, new machines, new developments, new production methods
- Send your scouts and scientists on month-long missions to find that rare beetle somewhere in the Arctic ice or learn how to use that new technology you need to unlock a fourth or fifth level of an ingredient.
- Expand, start with new ingredients, new cures, do it all over again!

It's a sandbox game and feels a lot more like Transport Tycoon or Infinifactory than Theme Hospital, you have your input (a plant, an insect, any kind of biological source), you refine it, mix it, filter it, strengthen or weaken specific effects, create a smooth running cycle with dozens of machines or steps in between, then export it as a medication in various forms. Pills or syringes? All your choice. Then you get rid of the side-effects, mix in other incredients, improve, get your A+ cure out and feel proud!

Play with or without competition, maybe you just like to make it look good and not fight with other companies? Your call!

If you like games like Infinifactory / SpaceChem or Transport Tycoon you will love this game.
If you expect a simulation where small changes can affect the outcome on the long run you will love this game.
If you expect the humor of curing patients like you did in Theme Hospital, this game might appeal, but wont fill that need.

Overall it's a big recommendation if you like slow moving steady games, it'll often take hours to set things up well-running, and it's all about patience.
